commit_message:
Add domain roles APIs

Update the API in order to allow:
- CRUD of domain roles;
- Management of domain roles membership;
- Assignment of domain roles.

Implements: bp role-groups

Change-Id: Ifc1f2d9f07cb0df142f3076c6cc27c8449000ee7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone-specs refs/changes/31/139531/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Domain Roles: ``/v3/domain_roles/`` ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Domain roles are domain specific entities that allow a domain to support its own set of roles that are meaningful at that domain level. A domain role can map/contain one or more domain roles and/or global roles, that are referenced in policy files. Domain roles are not included in the role list that is part of a KeyStone token, rather they are resolved down to their underlying global roles at token generation time - and it is this set of global roles that will appear. Additional required attributes: - ``name`` (string) Globally unique name of the domain role. - ``roles`` (list) Represents the set of ``roles`` whose individual collection of actions are propagated. - ``domain_roles`` (list) Represents the set of ``domain_roles`` whose individual collection of actions are propagated. Example entity: :: { "domain_role": { "id": "32f49c", "roles": [ ], "domain_roles": [ ], "links": { "self": "http://identity:35357/v3/domain_roles/32f49c" }, "name": "vm-manager" } } Domain Roles ~~~~~~~~~~~~ The key use cases we need to cover: - CRUD on a domain role - Associating a role with a user or group on a project or domain Create domain role ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ :: POST /domain_roles Relationship: ``http://docs.openstack.org/api/openstack-identity/3/rel/domain_role`` Request: :: { "domain_role": { "name": "--domain-role-name--" } } Response: :: Status: 201 Created { "domain_role": { "id": "--domain-role-id--", "roles": [ ], "domain_roles": [ ], "links": { "self": "http://identity:35357/v3/domain_roles/--domain-role-id--" }, "name": "--domain-role-name--" } } List domain roles ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ :: GET /domain_roles Relationship: ``http://docs.openstack.org/api/openstack-identity/3/rel/domain_role`` Optional query parameters: - ``name`` (string) Response: :: Status: 200 OK { "domain_roles": [ { "id": "--domain-role-id--", "roles": [ ], "domain_roles": [ ], "links": { "self": "http://identity:35357/v3/domain_roles/--domain-role-id--" }, "name": "--domain-role-name--" }, { "id": "--domain-role-id--", "roles": [ ], "domain_roles": [ ], "links": { "self": "http://identity:35357/v3/domain_roles/--domain-role-id--" }, "name": "--domain-role-name--" } ], "links": { "self": "http://identity:35357/v3/domain_roles", "previous": null, "next": null } } Get domain role ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ :: GET /domain_roles/{domain_role_id} Relationship: ``http://docs.openstack.org/api/openstack-identity/3/rel/domain_role`` Response: :: Status: 200 OK { "domain_role": { "id": "--domain-role-id--", "domain_roles": [ { "id": "--domain-role-id--", "roles": [ ], "domain_roles": [ ], "links": { "self": "http://identity:35357/v3/domain_roles/--domain-role-id--" }, "name": "--domain-role-name--" } ], "roles": [ { "id": "--role-id--", "links": { "self": "http://identity:35357/v3/roles/--role-id--" }, "name": "--role-name--" } ], "links": { "self": "http://identity:35357/v3/domain_roles/--domain-role-id--" }, "name": "--domain-role-name--" } } Update domain role ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ :: PATCH /domain_roles/{domain_role_id} Relationship: ``http://docs.openstack.org/api/openstack-identity/3/rel/domain_role`` The request block is the same as the one for create domain role, except that only the attributes that are being updated need to be included. Request: :: { "domain_role": { "name": "--new-domain-role-name--" } } Response: :: Status: 200 OK { "domain_role": { "id": "--domain-role-id--", "roles": [ ], "domain_roles": [ ], "links": { "self": "http://identity:35357/v3/domain_roles/--domain-role-id--" }, "name": "--new-domain-role-name--" } } Add role to domain role ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ :: PUT /domain_roles/{domain_role_id}/roles/{role_id} Relationship: ``http://docs.openstack.org/api/openstack-identity/3/rel/domain_role_composite`` Response: :: Status: 204 No Content Remove role from domain role ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ :: DELETE /domain_roles/{domain_role_id}/roles/{role_id} Relationship: ``http://docs.openstack.org/api/openstack-identity/3/rel/domain_role_composite`` Response: :: Status: 204 No Content Add domain role to domain role ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ :: PUT /domain_roles/{domain_role_id}/domain_roles/{domain_role_id} Relationship: ``http://docs.openstack.org/api/openstack-identity/3/rel/domain_role_composite`` Response: :: Status: 204 No Content Remove domain role from domain role ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ :: DELETE /domain_roles/{domain_role_id}/domain_roles/{domain_role_id} Relationship: ``http://docs.openstack.org/api/openstack-identity/3/rel/domain_role_composite`` Response: :: Status: 204 No Content Delete domain role ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ :: DELETE /domain_roles/{domain_role_id} Relationship: ``http://docs.openstack.org/api/openstack-identity/3/rel/domain_role`` Response: :: Status: 204 No Content

subject: Raise minimum required neutronclient to >=2.4.0
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-10 14:03:51.000000000', 'files': ['global-requirements.txt'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/requirements/commit/d337e5a638c943d62a4eba8a63b2b5b6b520eadc', 'message': "Raise minimum required neutronclient to >=2.4.0

python-neutronclient 2.3.12 caps requirements from juno
global-requirements per commit 3f03a3bdb87782930eaf236f726f9bed7229e441
which is a problem since it's currently allowed into kilo and conflicts
with the minimum required versions of other libraries in kilo.

This makes grenade in kilo fail since neutronclient is installed as
2.3.12 on the old (juno) side but not upgraded on the new (kilo) side,
and then we hit version conflicts eventually with oslo.serialization.

The least of all evils at this point is to raise the minimum required
version of neutronclient to 2.4.0 in kilo since 2.3.* is all juno at
this point.

In retrospect we would have done a better job of bumping the minor
version in neutronclient releases when there are dependency changes so
we wouldn't have wedged ourselves like this, but there isn't much that
can be done about it now.  Hopefully most deployments that shippped kilo
were already using at least 2.4.0 and this isn't a problem for them.

Closes-Bug: #1482758

Change-Id: Ifda08076deb0026de4e1be83a98c08ac73f560f6
"}]
commit_message:
Raise minimum required neutronclient to >=2.4.0

python-neutronclient 2.3.12 caps requirements from juno
global-requirements per commit 3f03a3bdb87782930eaf236f726f9bed7229e441
which is a problem since it's currently allowed into kilo and conflicts
with the minimum required versions of other libraries in kilo.

This makes grenade in kilo fail since neutronclient is installed as
2.3.12 on the old (juno) side but not upgraded on the new (kilo) side,
and then we hit version conflicts eventually with oslo.serialization.

The least of all evils at this point is to raise the minimum required
version of neutronclient to 2.4.0 in kilo since 2.3.* is all juno at
this point.

In retrospect we would have done a better job of bumping the minor
version in neutronclient releases when there are dependency changes so
we wouldn't have wedged ourselves like this, but there isn't much that
can be done about it now.  Hopefully most deployments that shippped kilo
were already using at least 2.4.0 and this isn't a problem for them.

Closes-Bug: #1482758

Change-Id: Ifda08076deb0026de4e1be83a98c08ac73f560f6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/requirements refs/changes/74/211174/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
api: fix alarm deletion and update

The API allow the actions to be null.

This allow the alarm to be deleted and updated in this case.

Backported from:

https://github.com/openstack/aodh/commit/b40b4513e61cd76a11e031d5b77bffbda1d012f6

Closes bug: #1479274

Change-Id: Id29ede93951e9d21bf5e6416955ae096a1259d72

commit_message:
change deprecated assertEquals to assertEqual

fix against H234: assertEquals() logs a DeprecationWarning
in Python3.x. use assertEqual() instead.

Closes-bug: #1480776

Change-Id: Iffda6bb5f2616d4af4567eeea37bb26531e34371
Signed-off-by: Hiroshi Miura <miurahr@nttdata.co.jp>

commit_message:
Allow freezer-scheduler to find freezerc binary in a non-activated virtualenv

When in the case of a non-activated virtualenv, freezer-scheduler was no able
to find the freezerc binary because it search it with distutils find_executable
which uses os.environ['path'] and not sys.path.

If the binary is not found, we now fall back to sys.path

Change-Id: Ia0b70e0abbe13a8421f5fe2725831f06318cbe45
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/freezer refs/changes/94/211594/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if self.freezerc_executable is None: # Needed in the case of a non-activated virtualenv self.freezerc_executable = spawn.find_executable( 'freezerc', path=':'.join(sys.path))

commit_message:
Make context plugins decide how to map their data for scenario

Previously to have only one user and its context during the run
of scenario we had hack inside base runner to map full context
for scenario.

This patch makes context classes resposible for that. E.g. you
can implement method that will somehow map resources of context
for each run of scenario.

Fix context.__init__() methods they shouldn't change context
object.

There are 3 great benifits of this change:

- You don't need hacks to map resources created by context
  for scenarios, which will be crucial for other projects

- You don't need hacks to make mapping strategies configurable
  e.g. pick users randomly or 1 by 1 and so on

- Rally framework depends less on OpenStack stuff

Change-Id: Ie5915cd35b27cb1988465ba33179721bf61224c7

commit_message:
Bump version to 7.0. Update code from upstream repo

1. Bump version to 7.0

2. Use perestroika v5 repo schema

3. Fixing pool permissions after rsync
This change corrects the permissions of the pool folder so that it can
be consumed as a repository mirror via nginx.

4. Add packages (deb, rpm) specs

Related-bug: #1478118
Related-bug: #1476561
Change-Id: Iada03ddab5b7d551f13692cb1c87a634c2f10947

Update public key for devops repo

Since key for devops repo [1] was changed, we need to update it:

commit_message:
adopt ec2 api to work with keystone v3 api

Change-Id: I538c438b2378d78bfdcffaa0287109d9a6431b2f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ec2-api refs/changes/76/211576/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from keystoneclient import client as keystone_client from keystoneclient.v2_0 import client as keystone_client_v2 from keystoneclient.v3 import client as keystone_client_v3 # TODO(andrey-mp): keystone v3 allows to pass domain_name # or domain_id to auth. This code should support this feature._keystone_client_class = None def get_keystone_client_class(): global _keystone_client_class if _keystone_client_class is None: keystone = keystone_client.Client(auth_url=CONF.keystone_url) if isinstance(keystone, keystone_client_v2.Client): _keystone_client_class = keystone_client_v2.Client elif isinstance(keystone, keystone_client_v3.Client): _keystone_client_class = keystone_client_v3.Client else: raise exception.EC2KeystoneDiscoverFailure() return _keystone_client_class keystone_client_class = get_keystone_client_class() keystone = keystone_client_class( project_name=CONF.admin_tenant_name,
deleted_lines: from keystoneclient.v2_0 import client as keystone_client keystone = keystone_client.Client(

subject: Use pip to install the package
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-11 13:26:33.000000000', 'files': ['install.sh'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ec2-api/commit/baed639e8233b03a3e9c3a8f6f95afae8ef50897', 'message': 'Use pip to install the package

The installation by pip do not deeply scan requirements. For example it
allows
SQLAlchemy==1.0.5
sqlalchemy-migrate==0.9.6
for requirements
SQLAlchemy>=0.9.7,<1.1.0
sqlalchemy-migrate>=0.9.6
despite sqlalchemy-migreate v0.9.6 requires SQLAlchemy<=0.9.99.

The installation by direct call of setup.py downgrades installed
packages of DefStack installation, which may lead to problems.

Since DevStack uses pip to install packages, ec2api should install
packages by the same manner.

Change-Id: I5b02b4c318ba96e8e6855d921bef96d90f5f1c45
'}]
commit_message:
Use pip to install the package

The installation by pip do not deeply scan requirements. For example it
allows
SQLAlchemy==1.0.5
sqlalchemy-migrate==0.9.6
for requirements
SQLAlchemy>=0.9.7,<1.1.0
sqlalchemy-migrate>=0.9.6
despite sqlalchemy-migreate v0.9.6 requires SQLAlchemy<=0.9.99.

The installation by direct call of setup.py downgrades installed
packages of DefStack installation, which may lead to problems.

Since DevStack uses pip to install packages, ec2api should install
packages by the same manner.

Change-Id: I5b02b4c318ba96e8e6855d921bef96d90f5f1c45
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ec2-api refs/changes/75/211575/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if ! command -v pip >/dev/null; then sudo apt-get install python-pip fi$SUDO_PREFIX pip install -e ./

commit_message:
Add instruction how to run in legacy releases.

Change-Id: I84a9f71e026231c57cfeed34a05b19b24151b4e0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ec2-api refs/changes/74/211574/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Preferred way to run EC2 API in these releases is to run it in virtual environment: - create virtual environment by running command 'python tools/install_venv.py' - run install inside venv 'tools/with_venv.sh ./install.sh' - and then you need to run EC2 API services: 'ec2-api', 'ec2-api-metadata' and 'ec2-api-s3' Also you need to reconfigure metadata ports in nova(and neutron) config files if you want metadata to work correctly. (See 'Installation' section). After these steps you will have working EC2 API services at ports: 8788 for EC2 API and 3334 for S3 API. Don't forget to change keystone endpoints if you want to run some automated scripts relying on keystone information.

subject: add subsection around caching behavior and http
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-05-15 13:45:26.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/api-sig/commit/49504952e36a67f4019a3be3f0921ef8b253f801', 'message': "add subsection around caching behavior and http

One of the reasons things like the 501 debate go around in circles is
because the caching implications aren't being thought about. Caching
and Proxies are an extremely fundamental concept in HTTP, but often
skipped over by folks new to it. It's important to call it out
especially as the CORS support and javascript in browser native
clients are going to have dramatically different behavior here than
the python requests library that most people are familiar with.

commit_message:
add subsection around caching behavior and http

One of the reasons things like the 501 debate go around in circles is
because the caching implications aren't being thought about. Caching
and Proxies are an extremely fundamental concept in HTTP, but often
skipped over by folks new to it. It's important to call it out
especially as the CORS support and javascript in browser native
clients are going to have dramatically different behavior here than
the python requests library that most people are familiar with.

Change-Id: Ibc6eb07cb53e4dc5a8cee875d0eb356333465b1b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/api-sig refs/changes/23/183523/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: HTTP Caching and Proxy Behavior ----------------------- HTTP was designed to be proxied and cached heavily. HTTP caching by both intermediary proxies, and by clients themselves, is to be expected in all cases where it is allowed. This is a fundamental design point to allow HTTP to work at high scale. That means that anywhere in the HTTP spec that things are specified as cacheable, the server implement should assume that they are, and that it **may never see** follow up requests if it does not specify appropriate Cache-Control directives on cacheable responses. The following HTTP methods are defined as cacheable: HEAD, GET, and POST - [RFC 7231 section 4.2.3](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7231#section-4.2.3) Requests that return a status code of any of the following are defined as cacheable: 200, 203, 204, 206, 300, 301, 404, 405, 410, 414, and 501 [RFC 7231 section 6.1](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7231#section-6.1) Most python http client libraries are extremely conservative on caching, so valid RFC caching behavior won't be exercised. However, assuming "it works in the python toolchain" does not mean that it will in all cases. Especially with the coming support for CORS to allow native in browser javascript clients to our APIs the cache semantics will change dramatically.

commit_message:
Hyper-V: Fixes method retrieving free SCSI controller slot on V1

The method retrieving a free SCSI controller slot gets all the
related disk resources, checking their address using the
AddressOnParent attribute.

The issue is that this WMI object attribute is not available on the
V1 virtualization namespace, for which reason this method will raise
an AttributeError in case there disks connected to the SCSI
controller.

This patch fixes the issue by properly retrieving the disk address.

Closes-Bug: #1467916

Change-Id: I7f88e37ac6d13cd8a15b17939ec8dbdca2c988e1

commit_message:
Mistral documentation: Overview article

Partially implements: blueprint mistral-documentation

Change-Id: Iaa223357f1ad99e7c2e72b57ff121e15ef80c75f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/mistral refs/changes/42/209942/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Mistral is a workflow service. Most business processes consist of multiple distinct interconnected steps that need to be executed in a particular order in a distributed environment. One can describe such process as a set of tasks and task relations and upload such description to Mistral so that it takes care of state management, correct execution order, parallelism, synchronization and high availability. Mistral also provides flexible task scheduling so that we can run a process according to a specified schedule (i.e. every Sunday at 4.00pm) instead of running it immediately. We call such set of tasks and relations between them a workflow.Tasks Scheduling - Cloud Cron ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ A user can use Mistral to schedule tasks to run within a cloud. Tasks can be anything from executing local processes (shell scripts, binaries) on specified virtual instances to calling REST APIs accessible in a cloud environment. They can also be tasks related to cloud management like creating virtual instances, terminating instances and others. It is important that several tasks can be combined in a single workflow and run in on-schedule manner (i.e. on Sundays at 2.00 am). Mistral will take care of their parallel execution, if it's logically possible, as well as fault tolerance and will provide workflow execution management/monitoring capabilities (stop, resume, current status, errors and other statistics). Cloud Environment Deployment ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ A user or a framework can use Mistral to specify workflows needed for deploying environments consisting of multiple VMs and applications. Long-running business process ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ A user makes a request to run a complex multi-step business process and wants it to be fault-tolerant so that if the execution crashes at some point on one node then another active node of the system can automatically take on and continue from the exact same point where it stopped. In this use case the user splits the business process into a set of tasks and let Mistral handle them in a sense that it serves as a coordinator and decides what particular task should be started at what time. So that Mistral calls back with "Execute action X, here is the data". If an application that executes action X dies then another instance takes the responsibility to continue the work. BigData analysis & reporting ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ A data analyst can use Mistral as a tool for data crawling. For example, in order to prepare a financial report the whole set of steps for gathering and processing required report data can be represented as a graph of related Mistral tasks. As with other cases, Mistral makes sure to supply fault tolerance, high availability and scalability. Live migration ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ A user specifies tasks for VM live migration triggered upon an event from Ceilometer (CPU consumption 100%).The main idea behind Mistral service includes the following main points: - Ability to upload custom workflow definitions. - The actual task execution may not be performed by the service itself. The service can rather serve a coordinator for other worker processes that do the actual work and notify back about task execution results. In other words, task execution may be asynchronous thus providing flexibility for plugging in any domain specific handling and opportunities to make this service scalable and highly available. - The service provides a notion of task action which is a pluggable piece of logic that a workflow task is associated with. Out of the box the service provides a set of standard actions for user convenience. However, the user can create custom actions based on the standard action pack.

commit_message:
Skip Bandit Checks on Functional Test Code

To allow for fuzz testing to be added to functional tests without
tripping Bandit alerts, skip the Bandit checks for the functionaltests
directory.

Change-Id: I5bf003c264851248b5fa43eaf20ba0c8ddddd5ed
Related-Bug: #1481090

commit_message:
Add the authorization configuration options

Add the following two configuration options:

  * external = keystone.auth.plugins.external.DefaultDomain
  * methods = external, password, token, oauth1

Change-Id: I7e9b195bd0d87824771deb23b42608ba3ec58610
Closes-bug: #1482460
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cookbook-openstack-identity refs/changes/79/210179/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: describe '[auth] section' do it 'configures authorization options' do [ /^external = keystone.auth.plugins.external.DefaultDomain$/, /^methods = external, password, token, oauth1$/ ].each do |line| expect(chef_run).to render_config_file(path).with_section_content('auth', line) end end end

commit_message:
Suppress not image properties for image metadata from volume

Currently image metadata restored from a bootable volume has some
properties which are not properties of an original image. But Nova
stores these properties into system metadata of an instance booted from
the volume and into properties of snapshot image of the instance. This
leads to consuming of waste DB space, increases traffic with DB, and
confuses end users by unexpected image properties of instnace snapshot.

The reason is that Cinder stores image attributes (id, name, checksum,
etc) as volume image metadata together with true image metadata. Then
Nova loads this metadata and uses it as properties of image metadata as
is, with no modification.

This patch removes this artifical properties from loaded volume image
metadata.

Related-Bug: #1439819
Change-Id: Ic1155449aa47170ffd4e6e87e50de0a4cb5732da
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/47/204947/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Cinder stores these properties as volume image metadata for # a bootable volume, but they are not properties of a corresponding image. VIM_NOT_IMAGE_PROPERTIES = ( 'image_id', 'image_name', 'size', 'checksum', 'container_format', 'disk_format', 'min_ram', 'min_disk', ) for attr in VIM_NOT_IMAGE_PROPERTIES: properties.pop(attr, None)

commit_message:
Warnings are not shown any more in Welcome block on Dashboard

   - also little reshuffle: error warnings moved out recommendations block
   - fixed warning about unique "key" prop
   - removed unused states

Closes-Bug: #1482715

Change-Id: Ifa8809f472254e43120aa8f6acdc4b76eac2cf2b

subject: No project uses f_ prefix in filter params
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-07-05 15:04:06.000000000', 'files': ['guidelines/pagination_filter_sort.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/api-sig/commit/5c6c8c80ba50804b1f3b0750e3e01c2f50a716f4', 'message': 'No project uses f_ prefix in filter params

We should not introduce an f_ prefix recommendation for filtering
query parameters, since not a single project in OpenStack uses them.
This introduces pointless jitter to the API WG guidelines and the actual
APIs of our endpoints.

Change-Id: I4bbbd3c81fa93d76195a895557e91aeef012657b
'}]
commit_message:
No project uses f_ prefix in filter params

We should not introduce an f_ prefix recommendation for filtering
query parameters, since not a single project in OpenStack uses them.
This introduces pointless jitter to the API WG guidelines and the actual
APIs of our endpoints.

Change-Id: I4bbbd3c81fa93d76195a895557e91aeef012657b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/api-sig refs/changes/47/198547/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: parameters. GET /app/items?foo=buzz``/app/items?foo=buzz&baz=quux`` would provide no results. GET /app/items?foo=in:buzz,bar``?foo=in:"a,bc",d``. If values contain double-quotes, those can be``?foo="a\"b\"c"``.operation, and is performed as ``?param=foo``.``?size=gt:8`` and would return:: GET /app/items?size=gt:8Operators must be followed by colons, so the query ``?foo=gte`` searches forvalue as ``?foo="gte:"``.
deleted_lines: parameters. To avoid conflicts, filter parameters are prefixed with ``f_``. This is important to be able to filter on fields like ``limit`` and ``marker``. GET /app/items?f_foo=buzz``/app/items?f_foo=buzz&f_baz=quux`` would provide no results. GET /app/items?f_foo=in:buzz,bar``?f_foo=in:"a,bc",d``. If values contain double-quotes, those can be``?f_foo="a\"b\"c"``.operation, and is performed as ``?f_param=foo``.``?f_size=gt:8`` and would return:: GET /app/items?f_size=gt:8Operators must be followed by colons, so the query ``?f_foo=gte`` searches forvalue as ``?f_foo="gte:"``.

subject: RFC 5789 doesn't specify certain uses of PUT
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-07-08 14:48:53.000000000', 'files': ['guidelines/http.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/api-sig/commit/fc142b95829f8931e657e35c0a6f89f72607167c', 'message': "RFC 5789 doesn't specify certain uses of PUT

RFC 5789 allows omitting PUT fields only in so much as it doesn't
disallow them. Clarify that in the guidelines on PUT vs PATCH.

Change-Id: I84c4833e85a41904a6f84fb5fe682533f5a2c8d3
"}]
commit_message:
RFC 5789 doesn't specify certain uses of PUT

RFC 5789 allows omitting PUT fields only in so much as it doesn't
disallow them. Clarify that in the guidelines on PUT vs PATCH.

Change-Id: I84c4833e85a41904a6f84fb5fe682533f5a2c8d3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/api-sig refs/changes/97/199597/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: accept missing resource fields as unchanged from the server's saved state of the resource. :rfc:`5789` doesn't forbid using PUT in this way, but this method makes it possible to lose updates when dealing with lists or sets.
deleted_lines: accept missing resource fields as unchanged. This is valid under :rfc:`5789`, but makes it possible to lose updates when dealing with lists or sets.

commit_message:
Correct the usage of decorator.decorator

Correct the usage of decorator.decorator as described in [1].

[1]http://pythonhosted.org/decorator/documentation.html#decorator-decorator

Change-Id: Ia71b751f364e09541faecf6a43f252e0b856558e
Closes-Bug: #1483464
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/magnum refs/changes/98/211398/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @decorator.decorator def wrapped(func, *args, **kwargs): obj = args[1] bay = objects.Bay.get_by_uuid(pecan.request.context, obj.bay_uuid) baymodel = objects.BayModel.get_by_uuid(pecan.request.context, bay.baymodel_id) if baymodel.coe not in bay_types: raise exception.InvalidParameterValue( 'Cannot fulfill request with a %(bay_type)s bay, ' 'expecting a %(supported_bay_types)s bay.' % {'bay_type': baymodel.coe, 'supported_bay_types': '/'.join(bay_types)}) return func(*args, **kwargs) return wrapped
deleted_lines: def decorate(func): @decorator.decorator def handler(func, *args, **kwargs): obj = args[1] bay = objects.Bay.get_by_uuid(pecan.request.context, obj.bay_uuid) baymodel = objects.BayModel.get_by_uuid(pecan.request.context, bay.baymodel_id) if baymodel.coe not in bay_types: raise exception.InvalidParameterValue( 'Cannot fulfill request with a %(bay_type)s bay, ' 'expecting a %(supported_bay_types)s bay.' % {'bay_type': baymodel.coe, 'supported_bay_types': '/'.join(bay_types)}) return func(*args, **kwargs) return handler(func) return decorate

This patchset is follows steps put forth in the approved nova spec to
remove 'v3' from nova API code tree. We first move existing default V2
code into a directory named 'legacy_v2'. This moves the files and updates
all references to them. We then move all v2.1 code into the proper
directories, updating all references to them.

Closes-Bug: #1462901

Change-Id: I96727c5de36ee2a9b225523b8e795928dc26711a
"}, {'number': 13, 'created': '2015-07-22 21:48:54.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/7d27bdeed3ae271674c6a5b999e4bb50cec2a63b', 'message': "Remove v3 from nova API code tree

This patchset does the following to nova.api.openstack.compute:

1) Moves the existing default code for v2 into a 'legacy_v2' directory
2) Updates all references to the old default classes to the legacy path
3) Moves the v21 code out of the v3 directory and into the default
4) Update all references to the v3 paths to the default path
5) Deletes the v3 directory

Closes-Bug: #1462901

Change-Id: I96727c5de36ee2a9b225523b8e795928dc26711a

commit_message:
Move existing V2 to legacy_v2

The first step in the code cleanup for removing the API V3 references is
to move the existing default V2 code into a directory named 'legacy_v2'.
This moves the files, and updates all references to them.

There are some reference for keeping v2 API api-paste.ini entry and options
works as before.

* Add reference for RateLimit Middleware in 'nova/api/openstack/compute/limits.py'
* Add reference for Versions Middleware in 'nova/api/openstack/compute/versions.py'
* Add reference for osapi_compute_extension option's value in
  'nova/api/openstack/compute/contrib/__init__.py'

Partial-Bug: #1462901

commit_message:
Fix filtering nodes by labels

Closes-Bug: #1483702

Change-Id: Ia0f7396df7f4fa0df6f69a60f4fcb65d2bf144c0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web refs/changes/73/211573/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if (_.contains(this.getNodeLabels(), filter)) { var values = _.uniq(_.reject(this.props.nodes.getLabelValues(filter), _.isUndefined)); getNodeLabels: function() { return _.chain(this.props.nodes.pluck('labels')).flatten().map(_.keys).flatten().uniq().value(); }, var screenNodesLabels = this.getNodeLabels();
deleted_lines: if (_.contains(this.props.screenNodesLabels, filter)) { var values = _.uniq(_.reject(this.props.screenNodes.getLabelValues(filter), _.isUndefined)); var screenNodesLabels = _.chain(nodes.pluck('labels')).flatten().map(_.keys).flatten().uniq().value();

subject: Move the v3 files into the main directories
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-06 21:53:58.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/b2e72410d606f39517495080c956eaca5fdb255f', 'message': "Move the v3 files into the main directories

WIP - do not merge.

This step gets rid of all of the 'v3' directories, as they are no longer
needed, and moves the contents into the main API directories. All of the
existing v2 code has been moved into the 'legacy_v2' directories, and
the former v3 code will now be in the standard development location.
Also, as many references to 'v3' in the code as we could find have been
replaced with 'v21'.

Change-Id: I81309b01a1871ceb11ef1dcd9c480be6942ce7e6
Partial-Bug: #1462901

commit_message:
Move the v3 files into the main directories

WIP - do not merge.

This step gets rid of all of the 'v3' directories, as they are no longer
needed, and moves the contents into the main API directories. All of the
existing v2 code has been moved into the 'legacy_v2' directories, and
the former v3 code will now be in the standard development location.
Also, as many references to 'v3' in the code as we could find have been
replaced with 'v21'.

Change-Id: I81309b01a1871ceb11ef1dcd9c480be6942ce7e6
Partial-Bug: #1462901

commit_message:
scalar-unit data type support as template input parameters

Rounding scalr-unit.size to next GB if it value is not multiples
of GBs.

Added unittest cases
modified messages and exception string as per i18n standard

Change-Id: Ia3bb82d4d0b9596376fec80a8b8b803352d94975
Closes-Bug: #1474142

commit_message:
Neutron-Ironic integration patch

This patch is in preparation for the integration
of Ironic and Neutron. A new vnic_type is being
added so that ML2 drivers can filter for all
Ironic ports based upon match for 'baremetal'.
Nova/Ironic will set this vnic_type when issuing
port-create request to neutron.
(e.g. binding:vnic_type = 'baremetal' )

Change-Id: I25dc9472b31db052719db503a10c1fb1a55572ef
Partial-Implements: blueprint neutron-ironic-integration

added_lines: import eventlet def test_port_qos_disassociation(self): """Test that qos_policy_id set to None will remove all qos rules from given port. """ self.set_test_qos_rules(TEST_POLICY_ID1, [TEST_BW_LIMIT_RULE_1]) port_dict = self._create_test_port_dict() port_dict['qos_policy_id'] = TEST_POLICY_ID1 self.setup_agent_and_ports([port_dict]) self.wait_until_ports_state(self.ports, up=True) eventlet.sleep(1) eventlet.sleep(1) eventlet.sleep(1) self._assert_bandwidth_limit_rule_is_set(port_dict, TEST_BW_LIMIT_RULE_1) port_dict['qos_policy_id'] = None self.agent.port_update(None, port=port_dict) eventlet.sleep(1) eventlet.sleep(1) eventlet.sleep(1) self._assert_bandwidth_limit_rule_not_set(port_dict) def test_port_qos_update_policy_id(self): """Test that change of qos policy id on given port refreshes all its rules. """ self.set_test_qos_rules(TEST_POLICY_ID1, [TEST_BW_LIMIT_RULE_1]) port_dict = self._create_test_port_dict() port_dict['qos_policy_id'] = TEST_POLICY_ID1 self.setup_agent_and_ports([port_dict]) self.wait_until_ports_state(self.ports, up=True) # HOW CAN I SYNCHRONIZE THIS??!! eventlet.sleep(1) eventlet.sleep(1) eventlet.sleep(1) self._assert_bandwidth_limit_rule_is_set(port_dict, TEST_BW_LIMIT_RULE_1) self.set_test_qos_rules(TEST_POLICY_ID2, [TEST_BW_LIMIT_RULE_2]) port_dict['qos_policy_id'] = TEST_POLICY_ID2 self.agent.port_update(None, port=port_dict) eventlet.sleep(1) eventlet.sleep(1) eventlet.sleep(1) self._assert_bandwidth_limit_rule_is_set(port_dict, TEST_BW_LIMIT_RULE_2)

commit_message:
Implement transactions for create_qos_bw_limit_for_port

Add rollback capability in create_qos_bw_limit_for_port so that
the multiple changes will be rolled back if the transaction fails.

Co-Authored-By: James Reeves <james.reeves5546@gmail.com>

Change-Id: I77c7c8be413b0736c2775552079f2df28dc2e130

commit_message:
Ironic:check the configuration item api_max_retries

we need to to check the value of the configuration item api_max_retries in
the code in order to ensure the " api_max_retries " equal or bigger than 0
,done like that the configuration item network_allocate_retries

Co-Authored-By: Kevin_Zheng <zhengzhenyu@huawei.com>

Change-Id: I034d726398b4bdabd34f96a3b30ae4d48c1d3fb6
Closes-Bug: #1372432

subject: Remove newlines in base64.encodestring
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-01-27 11:46:04.000000000', 'files': ['ceilometer/tests/api/v2/test_list_meters_scenarios.py', 'ceilometer/api/controllers/v2.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer/commit/999bd00f09f58e78b51b3cc74d43f885c1de7428', 'message': 'Remove newlines in base64.encodestring

MIME specifies a maximum line length of 76 characters, most
implementations of base64 use a newline to delimit encoded lines.
Since we use it as uuid, the delimit is not necessary.

Meanwhile, base64.encodestring will always add an extra newline in
the end of returned string, for short string, end user will notice
this newline delimiter in ReST API but it just disappears in CLI API
because our CLI utils ignore the newline silently.

returned value.

Change-Id: I20e2a474e29037ec0596084d98a7fec6c4bd6021
ref: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Base64#MIME
Closes-Bug: #1271530
'}]
commit_message:
Remove newlines in base64.encodestring

MIME specifies a maximum line length of 76 characters, most
implementations of base64 use a newline to delimit encoded lines.
Since we use it as uuid, the delimit is not necessary.

Meanwhile, base64.encodestring will always add an extra newline in
the end of returned string, for short string, end user will notice
this newline delimiter in ReST API but it just disappears in CLI API
because our CLI utils ignore the newline silently.

This patch removes all newline characters in base64.encodestring
returned value.

Change-Id: I20e2a474e29037ec0596084d98a7fec6c4bd6021
ref: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Base64#MIME
Closes-Bug: #1271530

commit_message:
Create flavors from registered nodes

Adds the ability to query Ironic for already registered nodes
and create flavors that match those nodes.

Change-Id: I2ab56331b79a70c2584c2423a31cddd3e5613dce

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-10 20:57:27.000000000', 'files': ['nova_powervm/tests/virt/powervm/disk/test_localdisk.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova-powervm/commit/a559db0b66df245f26d17ead0a5dd00b24031c27', 'message': 'DNM: Example of using FeedTaskFx

commit_message:
DNM: Example of using FeedTaskFx

Change-Id: I7af9c7e2bd52da448e3f5597164ebcc6dc10b8a6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-powervm refs/changes/28/211328/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from pypowervm.tests import test_fixtures as pvm_fxfrom pypowervm.utils import transaction as pvm_tx def test_disconnect_image_disk_efried(self): # vio_to_vg is a single-entry response. Wrap it and put it in a list # to act as the feed for FeedTaskFx and FeedTask. feed = [pvm_vios.VIOS.wrap(self.vio_to_vg)] ftfx = pvm_fx.FeedTaskFx(feed) # Have to fake out EntryWrapper.update for now update_patch = pvm_fx.LoggingPatcher( ftfx, 'update', 'pypowervm.wrappers.entry_wrapper.EntryWrapper.update', return_value=feed[0]) # Patch up remove_maps, the crux of this test case. I could have done # this with @mock.patch just as easily. But this demonstrates adding a # new, arbitrary patcher to the fixture - and allows us to use a Logger rm_maps_patch = pvm_fx.LoggingPatcher( ftfx, 'remove_maps', 'pypowervm.tasks.scsi_mapper.remove_maps', return_value=True) ftfx.add_patchers(update_patch, rm_maps_patch) self.useFixture(ftfx) # I could access these inline as ftfx.patchers[name].mock too. mock_update = update_patch.mock mock_rm_maps = rm_maps_patch.mock # Need the driver to return the actual UUID of the VIOS in the feed, # to match the FeedTask. self.mock_vg_uuid.return_value = (feed[0].uuid, 'vg_uuid') local = self.get_ls(self.apt) inst = mock.Mock(uuid=fx.FAKE_INST_UUID) tx_mgr = pvm_tx.FeedTask('localdisk', feed) # 1) As initialized above, remove_maps returns True to trigger update. local.disconnect_image_disk(mock.MagicMock(), inst, tx_mgr, disk_type=[disk_dvr.DiskType.BOOT]) self.assertEqual(1, mock_rm_maps.call_count) self.assertEqual(1, mock_update.call_count) # If you want, you can inspect the log self.assertEqual(['lock', 'remove_maps', 'update', 'unlock'], ftfx.get_log()) # 2) Make remove_maps return False - update should not be called. mock_rm_maps.reset_mock() mock_update.reset_mock() ftfx.reset_log() # Note I have to modify the *patcher* (not the mock). And to clarify # any ambiguity, I called that member 'ret' instead of 'return_value'. rm_maps_patch.ret = False # Need a new FeedTask - else we keep adding subtasks to the same one. tx_mgr = pvm_tx.FeedTask('localdisk', feed) local.disconnect_image_disk(mock.MagicMock(), inst, tx_mgr, disk_type=[disk_dvr.DiskType.BOOT]) # remove_maps called, update not called self.assertEqual(1, mock_rm_maps.call_count) self.assertEqual(0, mock_update.call_count) self.assertEqual(['lock', 'remove_maps', 'unlock'], ftfx.get_log())

commit_message:
Use VIOS wwpns mapped target wwpns and luns

Exposes an interface which allows to build the ITLs
by identifying the exact map of target wwpns and luns based
on vios wwpns.
A new member variable is added which keeps track of
the number of vioses on which the hdisk is discovered and
connected successfully.

Change-Id: I2957811a22e637b7110fd13dd006c95370900b46
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-powervm refs/changes/23/209423/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _build_udid_key(vios_uuid, volume_id): """This method will build the udid dictionary key. :param vios_uuid: The UUID of the vios for the pypowervm adapter. :param volume_id: The lun volume id :returns: The udid dictionary key """ return vios_uuid + volume_id def __init__(self, adapter, host_uuid, instance, connection_info): """Initializes the vSCSI Volume Adapter. :param connection_info: Comes from the BDM. """ super(VscsiVolumeAdapter, self).__init__(adapter, host_uuid, instance, connection_info) self._pfc_wwpns = None def connect_volume(self): """Connects the volume. :param vm_uuid: The powervm UUID of the VM. it_map = self.connection_info['data']['initiator_target_map'] volume_id = self.connection_info['data']['volume_id'] vios_feed = vios.get_active_vioses(self.adapter, self.host_uuid, xag=_XAGS) # Get the mapped Targets and Lun t_wwpns, lun = self._get_targets_on_vios(vio_wwpns) self.adapter, vio_wrap.uuid, itls) self._add_mapping(vio_wrap.uuid, device_name) self._set_udid(vio_wrap.uuid, volume_id, udid) 'instance_name': self.instance.name} def disconnect_volume(self): volume_id = self.connection_info['data']['volume_id'] device_name = None volume_udid = None vios_feed = vios.get_active_vioses(self.adapter, self.host_uuid, volume_udid = self._get_udid(vio_wrap.uuid, volume_id) partition_id = vm.get_vm_id(self.adapter, self.vm_uuid) tsk_map.remove_pv_mapping(self.adapter, vio_wrap.uuid, hdisk.remove_hdisk(self.adapter, CONF.host, device_name, self.vm_uuid) 'instance_name': self.instance.name, def wwpns(self): self._pfc_wwpns = vios.get_physical_wwpns(self.adapter, self.host_uuid) def host_name(self): def _add_mapping(self, vios_uuid, device_name): pv = pvm_stor.PV.bld(self.adapter, device_name) tsk_map.add_vscsi_mapping(self.host_uuid, vios_uuid, self.vm_uuid, pv) def _set_udid(self, vios_uuid, volume_id, udid): udid_key = _build_udid_key(vios_uuid, volume_id) self.connection_info['data'][udid_key] = udid def _get_udid(self, vios_uuid, volume_id): """This method will return the hdisk udid stored in connection_info. :param vios_uuid: The UUID of the vios for the pypowervm adapter. :param volume_id: The lun volume id :returns: The target_udid associated with the hdisk """ try: udid_key = _build_udid_key(vios_uuid, volume_id) return self.connection_info['data'][udid_key] except (KeyError, ValueError): LOG.warn(_LW(u'Failed to retrieve device_id key from BDM for ' 'volume id %s'), volume_id) return None def _get_targets_on_vios(self, v_wwpns): """This method returns the target_wwpns and luns for the VIOS wwpns Each Virtual I/O server may have different mapped target wwpns and lun id, this method returns the mapped target wwpns and lun-id from the connection info based on the vios wwpns passed. """ it_map = self.connection_info['data']['initiator_target_map'] t_wwpns = [] for it_key in v_wwpns: t_wwpns.extend(it_map[it_key]) lun = self.connection_info['data']['target_lun'] return t_wwpns, lun

commit_message:
Fix oslo.messaging in neutron-server

oslo.messaging is breaking neutron-server or vice-versa. Either way
pinning oslo.messaging to the current stable fixes the issue. When
2.2.1 is stable or the delorean repos fix the issue we can remove the
pinning

Change-Id: I353aba463d0b1e11f4b58e5edd5241a636701172
Closes-Bug: #1483667

commit_message:
Use correct domain to find project

When adding a role to a group and project OSC is mistakenly using the
group_domain to find the project which will fail if the group_domain !=
project_domain.

Change-Id: I4c1bec9b3b183c755be121b91f40e026d707192b
Closes-Bug: #1483520

commit_message:
Allow to change root path for upstream ubuntu mirror

MIRROR_UBUNTU_ROOT=/pkgs/ubuntu is local copy of upstream ubuntu
mirror. We need to provide an ability to change this value while
using any other upstream mirrors, for example:
	MIRROR_UBUNTU_ROOT= \
	MIRROR_UBUNTU=ua.archive.ubuntu.com \
	MIRROR_MOS_UBUNTU=mirror.fuel-infra.org \
		make show-ubuntu-sandbox-repos

Change-Id: I30a74df5ebb4b3ca699fe692c6c076061328208e

commit_message:
Pass the extension driver exception to plugin

The extension driver is intercepted by driver manager currently. It will
cover the errors/exceptions happened in extension drivers. The extension
process will continue even if preceding extension driver get a wrong/useless
extended result, or even no result.
This patch make process_[create|update]_<resource>() and
extend_<resource>_dict() methods return the exception, and log it with proper
level respectively, and also include a minor optimization for the
extend_<resource>_dict() methods.

Change-Id: I20a249c47b58292125476bc44b2372ca959509e3
Closes-Bug: #1468990

commit_message:
Avoid dhcp_release for ipv6 addresses

dhcp_release is only supported for IPv4 addresses [1] and not for
IPv6 addresses [2]. There will be no effect when it is called with
IPv6 address. This patch adds a corresponding note and avoids calling
dhcp_release for IPv6 addresses.

[1] http://manpages.ubuntu.com/manpages/trusty/man1/dhcp_release.1.html
[2] http://lists.thekelleys.org.uk/pipermail/dnsmasq-discuss/2013q2/007084.html

Change-Id: I8b8316c9d3d011c2a687a3a1e2a4da5cf1b5d604

commit_message:
Added initial template for base image

Added new method generating Dockerfiles from templates as well as the
appropriate code to support this in build.py

Co-Authored-By: Sam Yaple <sam@yaple.net>
Partially-implements: bp dockerfile-template

Change-Id: Id14d10d31cb4aac957e04fbc129de4043d98e033
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/88/210288/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/usr/bin/env python from jinja2 import Environment, FileSystemLoader import optparse class Generator(): def __init__(self, options): self.tempdir = options.tempdir self.templates_dir = options.templates_dir self.os = options.os self.service = options.service self.install_type = options.install_type def generate(self): tempLoader = FileSystemLoader(self.templates_dir) env = Environment(loader=tempLoader) template = env.get_template(self.service) out = template.render(base_distro=self.os, install_type=self.install_type) outFileName = self.tempdir + '/Dockerfile' with open(outFileName, 'w') as f: f.write(out) def main(): p = optparse.OptionParser() p.add_option('--tempdir') p.add_option('--templates_dir') p.add_option('--os', default="centos") p.add_option('--service', default="keystone") p.add_option('--install_type', default="binary") options, arguments = p.parse_args() generator = Generator(options) generator.generate() if __name__ == '__main__': main()

commit_message:
Adds apply button to unsaved changes dialog

Introduces unsavedChangesMixin to pages where unsaved changes might
be lost. When these cases detected user gets a dialog
prompting to Cancel/Discard/Save their changes.

Change-Id: I3d370ed1fecdf35d70de98b09c00fc3d96a8d122
Closes-Bug: #1428633
Closes-Bug: #1340353
Closes-Bug: #1441093

commit_message:
[WIP]Definition of the Virtual Network Performance interface

Define the extension in neutron/extension/oam.py
and implement a service plugin for oam.

Implements:blueprint virtual-network-performance-monitor
Change-Id: Ia813948439867efcd8027ea4324dfdd7dabdb498

added_lines: # vim: tabstop=4 shiftwidth=4 softtabstop=4 # Copyright 2011 OpenStack Foundation. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from abc import abstractmethod from neutron.api import extensions from neutron.api.v2 import resource_helper from neutron.api.v2 import attributes as attr from neutron import manager from neutron.api.v2 import base from neutron.common import exceptions as qexception OAM="oam" OAM_PREFIXES='/oam' # Note: a default of ATTR_NOT_SPECIFIED indicates that an # attribute is not required, but will be generated by the plugin # if it is not specified. Particularly, a value of ATTR_NOT_SPECIFIED # is different from an attribute that has been specified with a value of # None. For example, if 'gateway_ip' is omitted in a request to # create a subnet, the plugin will receive ATTR_NOT_SPECIFIED # and the default gateway_ip will be generated. # However, if gateway_ip is specified as None, this means that # the subnet does not have a gateway IP. # The following is a short reference for understanding attribute info: # default: default value of the attribute (if missing, the attribute # becomes mandatory. # allow_post: the attribute can be used on POST requests. # allow_put: the attribute can be used on PUT requests. # validate: specifies rules for validating data in the attribute. # convert_to: transformation to apply to the value before it is returned # is_visible: the attribute is returned in GET responses. # required_by_policy: the attribute is required by the policy engine and # should therefore be filled by the API layer even if not present in # request body. # enforce_policy: the attribute is actively part of the policy enforcing # mechanism, ie: there might be rules which refer to this attribute. RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP={ 'vn_performance_management_oams': { 'id': {'allow_post': False, 'allow_put': False, 'validate': {'type:uuid': None}, 'is_visible': True, 'primary_key': True}, 'tenant_id': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': False, 'validate': {'type:string': None},# tenant_id is not a valid uuid 'required_by_policy': True, 'is_visible': True}, 'name': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'validate': {'type:string': None}, 'default': '', 'is_visible': True}, 'source_id': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': False, 'validate': {'type:uuid': None}, 'is_visible': True}, 'destination_id': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': False, 'validate': {'type:uuid': None}, 'is_visible': True}, 'test_type': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': False, 'validate': {'type:values': ['once','periodic']}, 'is_visible': True}, 'period_time': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': False,# optional 'validate': {'type:integer_or_none': [None,None]},# add _validate_integer_or_none 'default':None, #?? 'is_visible': True}, 'response_type': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': False, 'validate': {'type:values': ['normal','only_alarm']}, 'is_visible': True}, 'performance_type': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, # only in request 'validate': { 'type:dict': { 'reachability':{'type:boolean':None,'required':True}, 'delay':{ 'type:dict':{ 'delay_threshold':{'type:range':[None,None],'required':False}, 'delay_time':{'type:range':[None,None],'required':False}}, 'required':False }, 'jitter':{ 'type:dict':{ 'jitter_threshold':{'type:range':[None,None],'required':False}, 'jitter_time':{'type:range':[None,None],'required':False}}, 'required':False }, 'loss':{# add _validate_float in api.v2.attributes.py 'type:dict':{ 'loss_threshold':{'type:float':None,'required':False}, 'loss_rate':{'type:float':None,'required':False}}, 'required':False# persentage or float???? }, 'load_ratio':{'type:dict':{ 'load_ratio_threshold':{'type:float':None,'required':False}, 'load_raito_value':{'type:float':None,'required':False}}, 'required':False# persentage or float???? }}, }, 'is_visible': True}, # 'performance_report': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': False, # only in return # 'validate': {'type:values': ['TCP', 'HTTP', 'HTTPS']}, # 'default': None, # 'is_visible': True}, }, } class OamNotFound(qexception.NotFound): message = _("Oam %(id)s does not exist") class OamPluginInterface(extensions.PluginInterface): @abstractmethod def get_vn_performance_management_oams(self, context, **kwargs): pass @abstractmethod def get_vn_performance_management_oam(self, context,id,**kwargs): pass @abstractmethod def create_vn_performance_management_oam(self, context, **kwargs): pass @abstractmethod def update_vn_performance_management_oam(self, context, **kwargs): pass @abstractmethod def delete_vn_performance_management_oam(self, context,**kwargs): pass @abstractmethod def get_user_experience_management_oams(self, context, **kwargs): pass @abstractmethod def get_user_experience_management_oam(self, context,**kwargs): pass @abstractmethod def create_user_experience_management_oam(self, context, **kwargs): pass @abstractmethod def update_user_experience_management_oam(self, context, **kwargs): pass @abstractmethod def delete_user_experience_management_oam(self, context,**kwargs): pass class Oam(extensions.ExtensionDescriptor): @classmethod def get_name(cls): return "OAM service" @classmethod def get_alias(cls): return "oam" @classmethod def get_description(cls): return "Extension for OAM service" @classmethod def get_namespace(cls): return "http://wiki.openstack.org/neutron" @classmethod def get_updated(cls): return "2012-10-07T10:00:00-00:00" @classmethod def get_resources(cls): """List of extensions.ResourceExtension extension objects. Resources define new nouns, and are accessible through URLs. """ plural_mappings = resource_helper.build_plural_mappings( {}, RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP) attr.PLURALS.update(plural_mappings) resources = [] # resources = resource_helper.build_resource_info(plural_mappings, # RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP, # constants.CORE, # #register_quota=True # ) # COLLECTION_ACTIONS = ['index', 'create'] # MEMBER_ACTIONS = ['show', 'update', 'delete'] plugin=manager.NeutronManager.get_service_plugins()['OAM'] for collection_name in RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP: resource_name=plural_mappings[collection_name] params = RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP.get(collection_name, {}) collection_name = resource_name.replace('_', '-') + "s" controller = base.create_resource(collection_name, resource_name, plugin, params, allow_bulk=True, allow_pagination=True, allow_sorting=True) ex = extensions.ResourceExtension(collection_name, controller, path_prefix=OAM_PREFIXES, #member_actions= {'show':'GET', 'update':'PUT', 'delete':'DELETE'}, #collection_actions={'index':'GET', 'create':'POST'}, attr_map=params) resources.append(ex) return resources @classmethod def get_plugin_interface(cls): """Returns an abstract class which defines contract for the plugin. The abstract class should inherit from extesnions.PluginInterface, Methods in this abstract class should be decorated as abstractmethod """ return OamPluginInterface def update_attributes_map(self, attributes): super(Oam, self).update_attributes_map( attributes, extension_attrs_map=RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP) def get_extended_resources(self, version):#????? if version == "2.0":# for most extension,this field is 2.0 .I dont know what is the meaning of extend resource return RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP else: return {}

commit_message:
ObjectListBase support append and __delitem__

Adds support to nova.objects.base.ObjectListBase for the append() and
__delitem__() methods, which essentially pass through to the underlying
list of objects.

Change-Id: I5bd8e028e1d12f2c71b780d654dfd8f401f110d7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/47/210947/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class TestObjListBase(test.NoDBTestCase): def test_delitem(self): class MyList(base.ObjectListBase, base.NovaObject): fields = { 'objects': fields.ListOfObjectsField('MyObj'), } myobj = MyObj(foo=1, bar='baz', missing='apple') mylist = MyList(objects=[myobj]) self.assertEqual(1, len(mylist)) del mylist[myobj] self.assertEqual(0, len(mylist)) def test_append(self): class MyList(base.ObjectListBase, base.NovaObject): fields = { 'objects': fields.ListOfObjectsField('MyObj'), } myobj = MyObj(foo=1, bar='baz', missing='apple') mylist = MyList() self.assertEqual(0, len(mylist)) mylist.append(myobj) self.assertEqual(1, len(mylist))

Validation for plugin v3

Checking of proper structure for deployment_tasks.yaml,
node_roles.yaml and volumes.yaml metadata files

added_lines: # Copyright 2015 Mirantis, Inc.from os.path import join as join_path from fuel_plugin_builder.validators.schemas.v3 import SchemaV3 from fuel_plugin_builder.validators.validator_v2 import ValidatorV2 class ValidatorV3(ValidatorV2): schema = SchemaV3() def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs): super(ValidatorV3, self).__init__(*args, **kwargs) self.deployment_tasks = join_path( self.plugin_path, 'deployment_tasks.yaml') self.node_roles = join_path( self.plugin_path, 'node_roles.yaml') self.volumes = join_path( self.plugin_path, 'volumes.yaml') def validate(self): super(ValidatorV3, self).validate() self.check_deployment_tasks() self.check_node_roles() self.check_volumes() def check_deployment_tasks(self): self.validate_file_by_schema( self.schema.deployment_task_schema, self.deployment_tasks) def check_node_roles(self): self.validate_file_by_schema( self.schema.node_role_schema, self.node_roles) def check_volumes(self): self.validate_file_by_schema( self.schema.volume_schema, self.volumes)
deleted_lines: # Copyright 2014 Mirantis, Inc.from fuel_plugin_builder.validators.schemas import v3 from fuel_plugin_builder.validators import validator_v2 class ValidatorV3(validator_v2.ValidatorV2): schema = v3.SchemaV3()

commit_message:
Makes len(string) be extension method

It was possible to say both len(collection)
and collection.len() and the same goes for dicts
but no string.len().

Now len(string) can be used as both function and
method

Change-Id: Idc725b4c806de9298c3e1b89ba07500ebefa6f9a

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-04 19:40:36.000000000', 'files': ['yaql/language/exceptions.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/yaql/commit/aaff46735a416d968ebc76f337bfc4c41a574b43', 'message': "Better exception messages

When method is not found doesn't match supplied arguments

Change-Id: I84bd816b9963febee8fa31c7fba6ce4b1a878a6e
"}]
commit_message:
Better exception messages

When method is not found doesn't match supplied arguments
object representation should be logged instead of just its type
as the cause is not necessary object type

Change-Id: I84bd816b9963febee8fa31c7fba6ce4b1a878a6e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/yaql refs/changes/31/209231/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: u'Unknown method "{0}" for sender {1}'.format(name, sender)) u'No method "{0}" for sender {1} matches ' u'supplied arguments'.format(name, sender)) u'Ambiguous method "{0}" for sender {1}'.format(name, sender))
deleted_lines: u'Unknown method "{0}" for type {1}'.format(name, type(sender))) u'No method "{0}" for type {1} matches supplied arguments'.format( name, type(sender))) u'Ambiguous method "{0}" for type {1}'.format(name, type(sender)))

subject: *args/**kwargs were added to SmartType methods
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-03 23:02:31.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/yaql/commit/412aa7a09b4335421d2e3530251e61506e99302e', 'message': '*args/**kwargs were added to SmartType methods

It is likely that next yaql version may have additional parameters
to check/convert methods. But it is impossible to add parameter
without breaking old inheritors that do not expect those parameters.
The only solution is to add *args/**kwargs to each method from the
start so that old functions will just ignore new parameters

commit_message:
*args/**kwargs were added to SmartType methods

It is likely that next yaql version may have additional parameters
to check/convert methods. But it is impossible to add parameter
without breaking old inheritors that do not expect those parameters.
The only solution is to add *args/**kwargs to each method from the
start so that old functions will just ignore new parameters

Change-Id: I2b95a5111366ab488a7a9e3223481cc5579395ef

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-04 08:47:53.000000000', 'files': ['yaql/language/utils.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/yaql/commit/0d2818a89172372c4cd493ba41c0550d8ad57465', 'message': 'Make data converters extendable

Add optional parameter to utils.convert_input()
and utils.convert_output_data() representing function
that need to be called recursively. By default it will
be the version from utils. But consumers may write
extended versions of those functions that do additional

used for nested structures as well

Change-Id: Iff7dadf4a12a163676012baaa85292e3d3e8bedc
'}]
commit_message:
Make data converters extendable

Add optional parameter to utils.convert_input()
and utils.convert_output_data() representing function
that need to be called recursively. By default it will
be the version from utils. But consumers may write
extended versions of those functions that do additional
conversion and then call original function passing themselves
in added parameter so that those additional conversions be
used for nested structures as well

Change-Id: Iff7dadf4a12a163676012baaa85292e3d3e8bedc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/yaql refs/changes/80/208880/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def convert_input_data(obj, rec=None): if rec is None: rec = convert_input_data return tuple(rec(t, rec) for t in obj) elif isinstance(obj, MappingType): return FrozenDict((rec(key, rec), rec(value, rec)) return frozenset(rec(t, rec) for t in obj) elif isinstance(obj, IterableType): return six.moves.map(lambda v: rec(v, rec), obj)def convert_output_data(obj, limit_func, engine, rec=None): if rec is None: rec = convert_output_data result[rec(key, limit_func, engine, rec)] = rec( value, limit_func, engine, rec) return set_type(rec(t, limit_func, engine, rec) return seq_type(rec(t, limit_func, engine, rec) return list(rec(t, limit_func, engine, rec) for t in limit_func(obj))
deleted_lines: def convert_input_data(obj): return tuple(convert_input_data(t) for t in obj) elif isinstance(obj, MappingType): return FrozenDict((convert_input_data(key), convert_input_data(value)) return frozenset(convert_input_data(t) for t in obj) elif isinstance(obj, IterableType): return six.moves.map(convert_input_data, obj)def convert_output_data(obj, limit_func, engine): result[convert_output_data(key, limit_func, engine)] = \ convert_output_data(value, limit_func, engine) return set_type(convert_output_data(t, limit_func, engine) return seq_type(convert_output_data(t, limit_func, engine) return list(convert_output_data(t, limit_func, engine) for t in limit_func(obj))

commit_message:
Contexts interface refactoring

* Added methods to retrieve context keys, check data/function
   presence, delete data/function
* Recursion was eliminated
* collect_functions() was moved to the base class and uses inheritors
   get_functions() API
* Bugs in MultiContext were fixed
* Unit tests were added

Change-Id: Ibe3a1345546d1c44df55d02e6e3408ac0325e99a

commit_message:
Align requirements to Kilo's global requirements

To prevent some of the bugs that we have due to
conflicts in requirements, upper versions from Kilo's
global requirements were used.
RPM spec was also updated.

Change-Id: I37253e700bd6c7c1b409f20f4c422056eac2bf13
Closes-Bug: #1483203

commit_message:
remove Zabbix experimental feature because it has been moved to a fuel plugin

this change is a part of a set of changes:

fuel-library: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/182615/
fuel-main: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/182682/
fuel-web: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/182701/

Closes-Bug: #1455664
Change-Id: I3d3d89aaa38a515d32757c0ccd0aa86afab51db1

commit_message:
Add coordination util for service management

Tooz is a Python library that provides a coordination API. Its primary
goal is to handle groups and membership of these groups in distributed
systems.

This patch adds coordination util to Mistral, which makes use of Tooz
libary.

Change-Id: Icbf3086d01649af813727f0972d6d5b0631d6afb
Partially-Implements: blueprint mistral-service-api
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/mistral refs/changes/33/193433/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2015 Huawei Technologies Co., Ltd. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. import uuid from oslo_config import cfg from oslo_log import log import tooz.coordination LOG = log.getLogger(__name__) OPTS = [ cfg.StrOpt('backend_url', default=None, help='The backend URL to use for distributed coordination'), cfg.FloatOpt('heartbeat', default=10.0, help='Number of seconds between heartbeats for distributed ' 'coordination.'), ] cfg.CONF.register_opts(OPTS, group='coordination') class ServiceCoordinator(object): """Service coordinator. This class uses the `tooz` library to manage group membership. To ensure that the other agents know this agent is still alive, the `heartbeat` method should be called periodically. """ def __init__(self, my_id=None): self._coordinator = None self._my_id = my_id or str(uuid.uuid4()) self._started = False def start(self): backend_url = cfg.CONF.coordination.backend_url if backend_url: try: self._coordinator = tooz.coordination.get_coordinator( backend_url, self._my_id) self._coordinator.start() self._started = True LOG.info('Coordination backend started successfully.') except tooz.coordination.ToozError: self._started = False LOG.exception('Error connecting to coordination backend.') def stop(self): if not self._coordinator: return try: self._coordinator.stop() except tooz.coordination.ToozError: LOG.exception('Error connecting to coordination backend.') finally: self._coordinator = None self._started = False def is_active(self): return self._coordinator is not None def heartbeat(self): if self._coordinator: if not self._started: # re-connect self.start() try: self._coordinator.heartbeat() except tooz.coordination.ToozError: LOG.exception('Error sending a heartbeat to coordination' 'backend.') def join_group(self, group_id): if not self._coordinator or not self._started or not group_id: return while True: try: join_req = self._coordinator.join_group(group_id) join_req.get() LOG.info('Joined service group %s', group_id) break except tooz.coordination.MemberAlreadyExist: return except tooz.coordination.GroupNotCreated: create_grp_req = self._coordinator.create_group(group_id) try: create_grp_req.get() except tooz.coordination.GroupAlreadyExist: pass def leave_group(self, group_id): if self._coordinator: self._coordinator.leave_group(group_id) LOG.info('Left service group %s', group_id) def get_members(self, group_id): if not self._coordinator: return [] while True: get_members_req = self._coordinator.get_members(group_id) try: members = get_members_req.get() LOG.debug('Members of group: %s', members) return members except tooz.coordination.GroupNotCreated: LOG.warn('Group %s does not exist.', group_id) return []

commit_message:
Glance bootstrap container does not create tables and runs forever

Due to typo in ansible/roles/glance/tasks/bootstrap.yml container
misses database initialization block and starts service instead.
Ansible hangs on waiting for bootstrap container exit.

Change-Id: Icf5ba68b47d65b22d6869e4b7b2d93e7edb8ed3b
Closes-Bug: #1483647

commit_message:
VPNaaS: Enable devstack plugin for tests

Now that the VPNaaS repo has a devstack plugin, we need to
(apparently :) enable it for tests, before removing VPN
related setup from the devstack repo.

Change-Id: I72af2d48f58d885f8872b149517c7fabe6ec8cf7

added_lines: Neutron relies on unit, functional, fullstack and API tests to ensure its quality, as described below. In addition to in-tree testing, `Tempest`_ iscomponents via scenario tests, and `Rally`_ is responsible for benchmarking.possible. They are designed to test the various pieces of the Neutron tree to make sure any new changes don't break existing functionality. Unit tests have no requirements nor make changes to the system they are running on. They use an in-memory sqlite database to test DB interaction.validate actual system interaction. Mocks should be used sparingly, if at all. Care should be taken to ensure that existing systemproperly cleaned up both on test success and failure. Fullstack Tests ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Fullstack tests (neutron/tests/fullstack/) target Neutron as a whole. The test infrastructure itself manages the Neutron server and its agents. Fullstack tests are a form of integration testing and fill a void between unit/functional tests and Tempest. More information may be found at: doc/source/devref/fullstack_testing.rst.and stability of the Neutron API. As much as possible, changes toto limit the potential for introducing backwards-incompatible changes, although the same patch that introduces a new API should include an API test. Since API tests target a deployed Neutron daemon that is not test-managed, they should not depend on controlling the runtime configuration of the target daemon. API tests should be black-box - no assumptions should be made about implementation. Only the contract defined by Neutron's REST APIneutron/tests/api was copied from the Tempest project. The Tempest networking API directory was frozen and any new tests belong to the Neutron repository. Development Processfixed! In addition, before proposing for merge, all of theStructure of the Unit Test Treethe name of the target module prefixed by `test_`. This requirementWhere appropriate, exceptions can be added to the above script. If code is not part of the Neutron namespace, for example, it's probablyRunning Testsunderstand the `load_tests protocol`_ introduced in Python 2.7. Thisversions of Python: 2.7 and 3.4IMPORTANT: configure_for_func_testing.sh relies on DevStack to perform extensive modification to the underlying host. Execution of thefollowing commands be invoked only on a clean and disposeable VM. A VM that has had DevStack previously installed on it is also fine. ::The '-i' option is optional and instructs the script to use DevStack to install and configure all of Neutron's package dependencies. It is not necessary to provide this option if DevStack has already been usedtools/configure_for_func_testing.sh is advised (As described above).To run the api tests, deploy Tempest and Neutron with DevStack andDevStack (/opt/stack/tempest/etc) it may be necessary to setRunning Individual TestsFor running individual test modules, cases or tests, you just need to pass the dot-separated path you want as an argument to it. For example, the following would run only a single test or test case: $ ./run_tests.sh neutron.tests.unit.test_manager $ ./run_tests.sh neutron.tests.unit.test_manager.NeutronManagerTestCase $ ./run_tests.sh neutron.tests.unit.test_manager.NeutronManagerTestCase.test_service_plugin_is_loaded $ tox -e py27 neutron.tests.unit.test_manager $ tox -e py27 neutron.tests.unit.test_manager.NeutronManagerTestCase $ tox -e py27 neutron.tests.unit.test_manager.NeutronManagerTestCase.test_service_plugin_is_loaded Coverage ~~~~~~~~ Neutron has a fast growing code base and there are plenty of areas that need better coverage.current unit tests coverage by running::are run. For pdb statements to work, invoke run_tests as follows::Tox packages and installs the Neutron source tree in a given venvPost-mortem Debugging

Mocks should be used sparingly, if at all. Care should be taken to ensure that existing systemproperly cleaned up.and stability of the Neutron API. Since API tests need to be able to target a deployed Neutron daemon that is not necessarily test-managed, they should not depend on controlling the runtime configuration of the target daemon. API tests should be black-box - no assumptions should be made about implementation. Only the contract defined by Neutron's REST APIDevelopment processfixed! This requirementWhere appropriate, exceptions can be added to the above script. If code is not part of the neutron namespace, for example, it's probablyVirtual environments ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Testing OpenStack projects, including Neutron, is made easier with `DevStack <https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack-dev/devstack>`_. Create a machine (such as a VM or Vagrant box) running a distribution supported by DevStack and install DevStack there. For example, there is a Vagrant script for DevStack at https://github.com/bcwaldon/vagrant_devstack. .. note:: If you prefer not to use DevStack, you can still check out source code on your local machine and develop from there. For example, the following would run only the JSONV2TestCase tests from neutron/tests/unit/test_api_v2.py:: $ ./run_tests.sh neutron.tests.unit.test_api_v2.JSONV2TestCase $ tox -e py27 neutron.tests.unit.test_api_v2.JSONV2TestCase Adding more tests ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Neutron has a fast growing code base and there is plenty of areas that need to be covered by unit and functional tests.current coverage by running::are run. commit_message:
ConsistencyGroup Object

This patch adds VersionedObjects abstraction layer to
consistency groups.

Change-Id: I3febb95bb2b3dd8f10da4f01ffa705e39cb20520
Partial-Implements: blueprint cinder-objects
Co-Authored-by: Daniel Tadrzak <daniel.tadrzak@intel.com>
Co-Authored-by: Michal Dulko <michal.dulko@intel.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/41/163641/33 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2015 Yahoo Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from oslo_config import cfg from cinder import db from cinder import exception from cinder.i18n import _ from cinder import objects from cinder.objects import base from cinder.objects import fields from cinder.openstack.common import log as logging from cinder import utils CONF = cfg.CONF LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) class ConsistencyGroup(base.CinderPersistentObject, base.CinderObject, base.CinderObjectDictCompat): Version = '1.0' fields = { 'id': fields.UUIDFields(), 'user_id': fields.UUIDField(nullable=True), 'project_id': fields.UUIDField(nullable=True), 'host': fields.StringField(nullable=True), 'availability_zone': fields.StringField(nullable=True), 'name': fields.StringField(nullable=True), 'description': fields.StringField(nullable=True), 'volume_type_id': fields.UUIDField(nullable=True), 'status': fields.StringField(nullable=True), 'cgsnapshot_id': fields.UUIDField(nullable=True), } def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs): super(ConsistencGroup, self).__init__(*args, **kwargs) def obj_make_compatible(self, primitive, target_version): """Make an object representation compatible with a target version.""" target_version = utils.convert_version_to_tuple(target_version) @staticmethod def _from_db_object(context, consistencygroup, db_consistencygroup): for name, field in consistencygroup.fields.items(): value = db_consistencygroup['name'] if isinstance(field, fields.IntegerField): value = value or 0 quota[name] = value consistencygroup._context = context consistencygroup.obj_reset_changes() return consistencygroup @base.remotable_classmethod def get_by_id(cls, context, id): db_consistencygroup = db.consistencygroup_get(context, id) return cls._from_db_object(context, cls(context), db_consistencygroup) @base.remotable def create(self, context): if self.obj_attr_is_set('id'): raise exception.ObjectActionError(action='create', reason=_('already_created')) updates = self.obj_get_changes() db_consistencygroups = db.consistencygroup_create(context, updates) self._from_db_object(context, self, db_consistencygroups) @base.remotable def save(self, context): updates = self.obj_get_changes() if updates: db.consistencygroup_update(context, self.id, updates) self.obj_reset_changes() @base.remotable def destroy(self, context): db.consistencygroup_destroy(context, self.id) class ConsistencyGroupList(base.ObjectListBase, base.CinderObject): VERSION = '1.0' fields = { 'objects': fields.ListOfObjectsField('ConsistencyGroup') } child_version = { '1.0': '1.0' } @base.remotable_classmethod def get_all(cls, context): consistencygroups = db.consistencygroup_get_all(context) return base.obj_make_list(context, cls(), objects.ConsistencyGroup, consistencygroups) @base.remotable_classmethod def get_all_by_project(cls, context, project_id): consistencygroups = db.consistencygroup_get_all_by_project(context, project_id) return base.obj_make_list(context, cls(context), objects.ConsistencyGroup, consistencygroups)

commit_message:
Remove duplicate code to load client

Since both the core plugin, l3, lbaas and in the future, ML2 driver all
need to initialize the midonet client the same way, move the loading
method to a common module to avoid code duplication.

Change-Id: Iea4d6fc607436e69ab9913639bfe688e42b67ab4
Partially-Implements: bp/midonet-ml2
Signed-off-by: Ryu Ishimoto <ryu@midokura.com>
