commit_message:
Speed up reaper for a big account delete and some better error handling

In run_forever mode, run the reaper on all three copies of the account
DB instead of just the first one and shard the containers between them.

Change-Id: Id182e89dad70df9d6d9988523861b8085d74c765
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/57/208057/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import socketfrom hashlib import md5 self.bind_port = int(conf.get('bind_port', 0)) self.shard_containers = False self.start_time = time() self.shard_containers = True if not os.path.isdir(partition_path): continue container_shard = -1 for node in nodes: container_shard += 1 if is_local_device(self.myips, None, node['ip'], None) and \ (not self.bind_port or self.bind_port == node['port']): break else: continue if not (self.shard_containers or container_shard == 0): # if you are not sharding containers, only process if this is # the primary account node self.reap_account( broker, partition, nodes, container_shard=container_shard) def reap_account(self, broker, partition, nodes, container_shard=0): :param container_shard: int used to shard containers reaped. container_limit = 1000 if self.shard_containers: container_limit *= len(nodes) list(broker.list_containers_iter(container_limit, marker, None, None, None)) if self.shard_containers and \ int(md5(container).hexdigest(), 16) % \ len(nodes) != container_shard: continue except (Timeout, socket.error) as err: self.logger.error( _('Timeout Exception with %(ip)s:%(port)s/%(device)s'), node) except (Timeout, socket.error) as err: self.logger.error( _('Timeout Exception with %(ip)s:%(port)s/%(device)s'), node) failures += 1 self.logger.increment('containers_failures') except (Timeout, socket.error) as err: failures += 1 self.logger.increment('objects_failures') self.logger.error( _('Timeout Exception with %(ip)s:%(port)s/%(device)s'), node)
deleted_lines: if (not is_local_device(self.myips, None, nodes[0]['ip'], None) or not os.path.isdir(partition_path)): self.reap_account(broker, partition, nodes) def reap_account(self, broker, partition, nodes): list(broker.list_containers_iter(1000, marker, None, None, None))

commit_message:
Change ansible forks used

This patch changes the number of forks used by ansible when
using any of the convenience (and thus gate check) scripts
to the number of processors available on the deployment
system.

The previous values used were found to cause ssh connection
errors and it was found that reducing the number improved
the chances of success.

This patch also removes the forks setting from ansible.conf
so that ansible will use the default value when run in any
other way. This leaves the decision of setting the number
of forks to the deployer, as it should be.

Change-Id: I31ad7353344f7994063127ecfce8f4733769234c
Closes-Bug: #1479812
(cherry picked from commit 7b10c64007a14e78b52b0afcfc2fa2f7b4e17ef3)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/26/209426/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: # Setting forks should be based on your system. The Ansible defaults to 5, # the os-lxc-hosts assumes that you have a system that can support # OpenStack, thus it has been conservatively been set to 15 forks = 15

commit_message:
Added gate process and more logs

This adds a forced apt update for packages and keys which is intended to help
with the HPB4 gate issues. This also creates logs for all ansible commands
run in the gate process.

Change-Id: I79b64567e615d83c52c1a8727082345ffe265c87
(cherry picked from commit a86d89f1a7b1d957130f6278363e693197aedb48)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/25/209425/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: COMMAND_LOGS=${COMMAND_LOGS:-"/openstack/log/ansible_cmd_logs/"}# Create a simple task to bounce all networks within a container. cat > /tmp/ensure_container_networking.sh <<EOF #!/bin/bash INTERFACES="" INTERFACES+="\$(awk '/auto/ {print \$2}' /etc/network/interfaces) " INTERFACES+="\$(ls -1 /etc/network/interfaces.d/ | awk -F'.cfg' '{print \$1}')" for i in \${INTERFACES}; do echo "Bouncing on \$i" ifdown \$i || true ifup \$i || true done EOF mkdir -p "${COMMAND_LOGS}/host_net_bounce" ansible hosts -m shell \ -a '(ifdown lxcbr0 || true); ifup lxcbr0' \ -t "${COMMAND_LOGS}/host_net_bounce" \ &> ${COMMAND_LOGS}/host_net_bounce.log mkdir -p "${COMMAND_LOGS}/lxc_existing_container_restart" ansible hosts -m shell \ -a 'for i in $(lxc-ls); do lxc-stop -n $i; lxc-start -d -n $i; done' \ -t "${COMMAND_LOGS}/lxc_existing_container_restart" \ &> ${COMMAND_LOGS}/lxc_existing_container_restart.log mkdir -p "${COMMAND_LOGS}/veth_cleanup" ansible hosts -m shell \ -a 'lxc-system-manage veth-cleanup' \ -t "${COMMAND_LOGS}/veth_cleanup" \ &> ${COMMAND_LOGS}/veth_cleanup.log mkdir -p "${COMMAND_LOGS}/flush_net_cache" ansible hosts -m shell \ -a 'lxc-system-manage flush-net-cache' \ -t "${COMMAND_LOGS}/flush_net_cache" \ &> ${COMMAND_LOGS}/flush_net_cache.log # Force the networks down and then up mkdir -p "${COMMAND_LOGS}/container_net_bounce" ansible all_containers -m script \ -a '/tmp/ensure_container_networking.sh' \ -t "${COMMAND_LOGS}/container_net_bounce" \ &> ${COMMAND_LOGS}/container_net_bounce.log # Force an apt-cache update for packages and keys throttling the processes. # * Note: that the task will always return 0. We want to see everything and # if it fails we want to see where it breaks down within the stack. # * Note: this is not using the apt module, because we want to FORCE it with raw. mkdir -p "${COMMAND_LOGS}/force_apt_update" ansible all_containers -m raw \ -a '(apt-get update && apt-key update) || true' \ --forks 10 \ -t "${COMMAND_LOGS}/force_apt_update" \ &> ${COMMAND_LOGS}/force_apt_update.log mkdir -p "${COMMAND_LOGS}/repo_data" ansible 'repo_all[0]' -m raw \ -a 'find /var/www/repo/os-releases -type l' \ -t "${COMMAND_LOGS}/repo_data"
deleted_lines: ansible hosts -m shell -a '(ifdown lxcbr0 || true); ifup lxcbr0' ansible hosts -m shell -a 'for i in $(lxc-ls); do lxc-stop -n $i; lxc-start -d -n $i; done' ansible hosts -m shell -a 'lxc-system-manage veth-cleanup' ansible hosts -m shell -a 'lxc-system-manage flush-net-cache'

commit_message:
Removed configuration option for qos agent driver selection

There is no (general) use case to allow users to configure qos driver to
load by qos l2 agent extension. So instead of getting the driver name
from the configuration file, hardcode it and potentially reuse for other
extensions that may also be interested in splitting extension into
agent agnostic and agent specific pieces.

Added driver_type parameter to AgentCoreResourceExtension.initialize().
Also updated the method signature to reflect that we expect l2
extensions to receive connection.

Finally, removed #noqa import for openvswitch.common.config from qos
extension unit test since it seems unneeded.

Change-Id: Iae4dcc20c967d1da216772a3a3660e0421263527
Partially-Implements: quantum-qos-api

- Change max_connection size for Mysql. This parameter is calculated
  based on RAM and Mysql buffers, but limited to 8192
- Worker formula is changed. It's limited to 2 in minimal case when
  server has only one CPU. Also, it's limited to 16 processes for
  servers that have more than 16 physical cores
- Haproxy backend has been adjusted to check galera backend via
  galeracheck script every 20 seconds instead of 15. In HA scenario, 3
  servers will call galeracheck every 5-7 seconds. When server is down
  haproxy will call every 2 seconds instead of one

commit_message:
Change max_connection size parameter for MySQL

Change max_connection size parameter for MySQL. This parameter is
calculated based on RAM and MySQL buffers, with upper bound to
8192 and lower bound to 1000 connections.

Co-Authored-By: Sergii Golovatiuk <sgolovatiuk@mirantis.com>

commit_message:
Correct thread handling in TranslationHook

TranslationHook was using a threading.local() to store an error
message however the threading.local() was being created in __init__
of the Hook. Hooks are not per request, so this wasn't really
working as planned.

Now, instead of using threading.local() at all, we just modify the
environ held by pecan (and later used by the
ParsableErrorMiddleware). environ is request-local.

This change feels a bit crufty because it is but because of the way
Exceptions are managed in the app there's not really any good way to do
it. We could consider changing the way Exceptions related to error
messages, but that would be a very large change.

Duplicated from similar change in aodh:
I463059df28f291cea0644b1a9908a907f146ba1f

Change-Id: Ie561ec7ee7ec8b6d4a535ba7b20569b5a1101878
Closes-Bug: #1481244
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/03/210503/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def after(self, state): # After a request has been done, we need to see if # ClientSideError has added an error onto the response. # If it has we need to get it info the thread-safe WSGI # environ to be used by the ParsableErrorMiddleware. if hasattr(state.response, 'translatable_error'): state.request.environ['translatable_error'] = (
deleted_lines: import threading def __init__(self): # Use thread local storage to make this thread safe in situations # where one pecan instance is being used to serve multiple request # threads. self.local_error = threading.local() self.local_error.translatable_error = None def before(self, state): self.local_error.translatable_error = None def after(self, state): if hasattr(state.response, 'translatable_error'): self.local_error.translatable_error = (

commit_message:
Add dependency on both keystone backends for Sahara

During creating Sahara templates both Keystone backends may be
unnavailable and we need add dependency on both backends.
Additional commit for Idf07556d229d7c656106ac749053bd474e5d5a47

Change-Id: I20d96feadc5efebddf758ff9370c8ec4941eb9e7
Closes-bug: #1479782

commit_message:
Use DeferredOVSBridge in setup_default_table

setup_default_table method in br-tun module fires multiple ofctl
calls. Using DeferredOVSBridge will help us save us few OVS calls.

Closes-Bug: #1259847

Change-Id: I2f01bae5d9efc5c6a6f577e92204c930eb1cf827

commit_message:
Determinable supported boot device list

Add the facility to return a determinable list of supported boot devices
that is specific to the node being queried.

Change-Id: I2818322858d8278205dcf59c42422fd7bb74d2a2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/54/197554/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Determinable supported boot device list ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/supported-boot-device-list This blueprint proposes to add the facility to return a determinable list of supported boot devices that is specific to the node being queried. Problem description =================== Current driver interface get_supported_boot_devices() does not provide for a means to access the node being queried, as a result a determinable list of supported boot devices that are specific to this node cannot be calculated. Example usage, if a node uses an architecture other than x86 e.g. SPARC, then PXE boot is not supported, and therefore should not be contained in the returned list. SPARC architecture supports WANBOOT and this should be returned. However to determine this the node's property "cpu_arch" needs to be accessed. Proposed change =============== Add "task" parameter to get_supported_boot_devices() interface. By providing a task parameter to the get_supported_boot_devices() interface a driver can then access the node specific to this query e.g. task.node, and from there can look at a nodes properties and correctly determine the list of supported boot devices to return. This change would be backwards compatible, using inspect to determine if a specific driver as implemented the "task" parameter or not, and showing a deprecation warning if "task" paramater has not been implemented. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None State Machine Impact -------------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Client (CLI) impact ------------------- None RPC API impact -------------- None Driver API impact ----------------- get_supported_device_list() is a member of the standard Management interface. This change would effect all drivers but would be implemented so that it's backward compatible, using inspect to determine if a driver supports the task argument or not. If not a deprecation warning would be shown. Nova driver impact ------------------ None Security impact --------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Scalability impact ------------------ None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- All in-tree driver and unit tests will be amended to include the new "task" parameter. Out of tree drivers will see a depracation warning until they implement the new "task" parameter. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: mattkeenan Work Items ---------- * Add "task" to get_supported_devices_list() in base driver * Add new management property definition to check if driver supports task parameter or not. * Update all in tree drivers adding task paramater * Update all unit tests affected by change Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Will update all affected unit tests Upgrades and Backwards Compatibility ==================================== Backwards compatibility is achieved by using python's inspect module to determine if a driver's get_supported_device_list() implementation includes a "task" parameter or not. If not it will be called without the "task" parameter and a deprecation warning will be shown. Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== Bug: https://bugs.launchpad.net/ironic/+bug/1391598 Review: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/188466

commit_message:
Add delete_port api to agent extension manager

This commit add delete_port api to the agent
extension manager, the agent extension and the qos
etension, and it update the ovs agent to call it upon
delete port.

Partially-Implements: bluerint ml2-qos

commit_message:
Increase Haproxy checks timeouts for MySQL/Galera

Haproxy backend has been adjusted to check galera backend via
galeracheck script every 20 seconds instead of 15. In HA scenario, 3
servers will call galeracheck every 5-7 seconds. When server is down
haproxy will call every 2 seconds instead of one

Co-Authored-By: Sergii Golovatiuk <sgolovatiuk@mirantis.com>

Change-Id: Ibd1a9a53a9e98e1989b04475c7dc6a01339ba2e0
Related-bug: #1475433

commit_message:
Add test case for LoadBalancer driver(2)

This patch completed the test case of LoadBalancer driver which
uses Neutron LBaaS as backend service. It also added a get_current
method in Senlin context module which actually invokes the
get_current method defined in oslo_context.

Change-Id: I8e5ab4c09f88ce52406187aa6e8fca7483934117
Closes-Bug: #1472852

commit_message:
Ubuntu bootstrap: reboot on boot failure

By default the initramfs starts an interactive shell if the root
filesystem image can't be downloaded. This behaviour is not suitable
for Fuel, so tell the initramfs to reboot.

Related-Bug: #1483188
Change-Id: I8c166de0b944dbbe1f5ea17641e2dbda90d97116

commit_message:
Refactor api tests for alarm history

This patch fixs a input of the helper function '_get_alarm_history()'
which used to get alarm data although it just referred 'alarm_id'.

This patch also delete unecessary '_get_alarm()'.

Change-Id: I371ea06f176f65b648068382071176235c9b480c

subject: test/unit: Replace python print operator with print function (pep H233, py33)
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-07-28 16:06:16.000000000', 'files': ['test/unit/common/test_db_replicator.py', 'test/unit/proxy/test_server.py', 'test/unit/__init__.py', 'test/unit/proxy/controllers/test_container.py', 'test/unit/test_locale/test_locale.py', 'test/unit/common/test_manager.py', 'test/unit/common/test_utils.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/c5b5cf91a984f80cc6cbe42735b242083d700542', 'message': "test/unit: Replace python print operator with print function (pep H233, py33)

'print' function is compatible with 2.x and 3.x python versions
Link : https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3105/

Python 2.6 has a __future__ import that removes print as language syntax,
letting you use the functional form instead

Change-Id: I94e1bc6bd83ad6b05695c7ebdf7cbfd8f6d9f9af
"}]
commit_message:
test/unit: Replace python print operator with print function (pep H233, py33)

'print' function is compatible with 2.x and 3.x python versions
Link : https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3105/

Python 2.6 has a __future__ import that removes print as language syntax,
letting you use the functional form instead

Change-Id: I94e1bc6bd83ad6b05695c7ebdf7cbfd8f6d9f9af
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/04/206604/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from __future__ import print_function print('test1') print('test2') print('test4', file=sys.stderr) print('test5') print('test6', file=sys.stderr) print('test8')
deleted_lines: print 'test1' print 'test2' print >> sys.stderr, 'test4' print 'test5' print >> sys.stderr, 'test6' print 'test8'

NeutronNetwork class was comparing $.dnsNameservers to

Closes-Bug: #1483428

commit_message:
default_dns from config was never used

NeutronNetwork class was comparing $.dnsNameservers to
null and only then using config parameters. However property
with list contract cannot be null as null (or missing) value will be
converted to empty list

Change-Id: Icc920e8979005446faf5c69eb9f22a1e8b7f054e
Closes-Bug: #1483428
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano refs/changes/48/211348/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - If: len($.dnsNameservers) = 0

commit_message:
Functional test for QoS policy bandwidth rule update

Creates a port in a policy, and subsequently modifies the
bandwidth limit rule in the policy, then verifies that the
new limits are assigned to the port.

Change-Id: I23fe45ef08618ad91567feb1707028e0a0bfe0d6
Partially-Implements: ml2-qos

commit_message:
make devstack up-to-date for Liberty

In this patch:

 * Correct network extensions are enabled for tempest
 * Unnecessary configurations are removed
 * Q_L3_ENABLED is moved to setting from functions

Change-Id: Iad84140093443519e9f3cee708d6a55cb50c8337
Partially-Implements: bp/clean-up-devstack-plugin
Signed-off-by: Ryu Ishimoto <ryu@midokura.com>

commit_message:
Top Nav is responsive and inherits from its theme

Horizon's top nav now uses <nav> and correcly implements
the Bootstrap HTML standards to make a responsive experience.

Partially-Implements: blueprint horizon-theme-css-reorg
Partially-Implements: blueprint bootstrap-html-standards

Change-Id: I73c5529ae477a17f10a17946ac7120969578a0ba

added_lines: .navbar-brand { display: block; // The 114 is a legacy value to push the context-menu over padding: 0 $padding-small-horizontal; &:before { content: ''; display: inline-block; height: 100%; vertical-align: middle; } img { vertical-align: middle; max-height: $navbar-height; } } .navbar { margin-bottom: 0; border-top: none; border-right: none; border-left: none; .navbar-toggle { border-color: transparent; } // Pushes the menu slightly down from the navbar li > .dropdown-menu { margin-top: 2px; } // Sets default values for upper arrow on navbar dropdowns .dropdown-menu { &:before, &:after { position: absolute; content: ''; } } // Defaults the arrow to the left side .dropdown-menu { &:before { top: ($navbar-dropdown-arrow-size + 1) * -1; left: $navbar-dropdown-arrow-offset - 1; border-right: $navbar-dropdown-arrow-size + 1 solid transparent; border-bottom: $navbar-dropdown-arrow-size + 1 solid $dropdown-border; border-left: $navbar-dropdown-arrow-size + 1 solid transparent; border-bottom-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.2); } &:after { top: -$navbar-dropdown-arrow-size; left: $navbar-dropdown-arrow-offset; border-right: $navbar-dropdown-arrow-size solid transparent; border-bottom: $navbar-dropdown-arrow-size solid $body-bg; border-left: $navbar-dropdown-arrow-size solid transparent; } } } // Changes the arrow to the right side for .navbar-right items .navbar-right .dropdown-menu { &:before, &:after { left: auto; } &:before { right: $navbar-dropdown-arrow-offset; } &:after { right: $navbar-dropdown-arrow-offset - 1; } }

commit_message:
highly distributed coordinated notifications

Change-Id: I4495fce88b4caa9cec023243a8122686a61bcd9f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/telemetry-specs refs/changes/31/199331/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================================ Highly Distributed Coordinated Notifications ============================================ Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ceilometer/+spec/disributed-coordinated-notifications In Kilo, support for coordinated notifications agents was added. This enabled users to deploy multiple notification agents and ensured related messages within a pipeline were funneled into the same agent to allow for proper aggregation calculations. Problem description =================== In the initial implementation, all the data was relating to a pipeline was funnelled into a single queue per pipeline. While it ensures all corresponding data is sent to the same place, it removes the ability to scale horizontally as the pipeline queues can only have a single consumer ever listening to it. This means that while multiple agents/handlers could be used to pull data off main OpenStack queue, once the data reached pipeline processing, it was relegated to a single worker. Data can be handled in parallel even at the pipeline level. For example, when there are no transformers, datapoints do not need to be handled sequentially. Additionally, when transformers are present, datapoints of different resources have no relevance to each other and can be handled in parallel. Proposed change =============== To parallelise and scale out processing, we will create multiple copies of each pipeline. When a datapoint arrives, we will bucketise each datapoint by resource id. The datapoints of each resource will be consistently sent to the same pipeline for processing. The basic workflow is as follows: - on notification agent startup, create a listener for main queue - for each pipeline definition, we create x queues and x listeners where x corresponds to the number of notification agents registered to group - when a datapoint is received, agent builds sample. - after sample is built, we hash (or don't hash) resource id (mandatory) and mod by number of agents. - using mod value we push datapoint to corresponding pipeline queue. - same processing steps here on out (listener grabs data -> pipeline -> pub) This is based on assumption we don't care about anything that spans resources. Alternatives ------------ Dumb easy fix is to detect whether a pipeline has transformers. If not, it can be consumed by any number of consumers and thus we can assign multiple listeners to those queues. This doesn't help distribute load of pipelines with transformers but allows for transformers spanning resources. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Pipeline impact --------------- Nothing from user point of view. Internally, we will have more pipeline queues. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Unless we decide to add option to define number of copies of pipeline queues. Performance/Scalability Impacts ------------------------------- Positive. It will distribute pipeline processing when running in coordinated mode. Message queues are consistently used with thousands of queues so creating copies of pipeline queues (a relatively small set) should not be an issue. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: <launchpad-id or None> Other contributors: <launchpad-id or None> Ongoing maintainer: <launchpad-id or None> Work Items ---------- - add support to detect number of agents registered - create pipeline queues based on the above number Future lifecycle ================ None. Dependencies ============ None. Testing ======= Test already exists. Just need to validate that we create appropriate amount of copies. Documentation Impact ==================== None. Maybe dev docs. References ========== https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1QgjDOLRnKDboqP8P1LvV0kR5aQEv_VJsDtMlh6u7tIY/edit?usp=sharing

commit_message:
Update setup Kolla development environment script

Change-Id: I256a71449ed237f59d5bdbd9c9c7ec51784ab1c8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/97/186297/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/bash # # This script is used to setup Kolla develop environment, # after running this script, you can run Kolla functional test. # NOTE: This script was only tested on redhat/debian/suse platform families. # set -xu DOCKER_MIN_VERSION=1.6.0 COMPOSE_MIN_VERSION=1.3.0 function check_prerequisites() { local flag=0 if [[ $EUID -ne 0 ]]; then echo You must execute this script as root. flag=1 fi if [ "$OSTYPE" != "linux-gnu" ]; then echo Platform not supported. flag=1 fi if [ "$HOSTTYPE" != "x86_64" ]; then echo Machine type not supported. flag=1 fi if ! type pip &>/dev/null; then echo You should install pip before running this script. echo Use one of the below commands to install: echo yum install python-pip echo apt-get install python-pip flag=1 fi [ $flag -ne 0 ] && exit 1 } function check_docker_version() { local docker_version local result if type docker &>/dev/null; then docker_version=$(docker --version 2>/dev/null | awk -F"[ ,]" '{print $3}') result=$(awk 'BEGIN{print '$docker_version' >= '$DOCKER_MIN_VERSION'}') if [ $result = 1 ]; then return 0 fi fi return 1 } function check_compose_version() { local compose_version local result if which docker-compose &>/dev/null; then compose_version=$(docker-compose --version 2>/dev/null | awk '{print $NF}') result=$(awk 'BEGIN{print '$compose_version' >= '$COMPOSE_MIN_VERSION'}') if [ $result = 1 ]; then return 0 fi fi return 1 } function start_docker() { pkill -x -9 docker if check_docker_version; then docker -d &>/dev/null & else curl -sSL https://get.docker.com/builds/Linux/x86_64/docker-$DOCKER_MIN_VERSION -o /usr/local/bin/docker chmod +x /usr/local/bin/docker /usr/local/bin/docker -d &>/dev/null & fi } function create_group() { getent group docker result=$? if [ $result -eq 0 ]; then # 0: key already exists, nothing to do return elif [ $result -eq 2 ]; then # 2: key could not be found in database groupadd docker chown root:docker /var/run/docker.sock usermod -a -G docker ${SUDO_USER:-$USER} else echo Unexpected failure: $result exit fi } function install_compose() { pip install docker-compose if ! check_compose_version; then pip install -e git://github.com/docker/compose#egg=docker-compose fi } function install_openstack_clients() { pip install python-keystoneclient python-glanceclient python-cinderclient \ python-neutronclient python-novaclient python-heatclient } # Check for root privileges and correct platform check_prerequisites # Start Docker service start_docker # Ensure executing user is placed in the docker group create_group # Ensure docker-compose is the supported version install_compose # Install OpenStack service clients install_openstack_clients

commit_message:
WIP: Follow Docker official guide to optimize Dockerfile

* Change ADD command to COPY
* Merge multi ADD/COPY commands to a single command
* Reduce image layers and size by merge Dockerfile commands
* Link: http://docs.docker.com/reference/builder/

Change-Id: I0442900b2aa54b98fa47206f5e6c5741a67ce1a6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/00/180500/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: COPY ./rabbitmq.config ./rabbitmq-env.conf /etc/rabbitmq/COPY ./start.sh /

subject: StorPool: clean up the last uses of str.format()
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-06-12 09:01:39.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/05e695c5f6ea452e1209eafadb9c3a75bf4ade0e', 'message': 'StorPool: clean up the last uses of str.format()

Replace three logging uses of str.format() with parameters passed
directly to LOG.error(), simplifying them in the process by
avoiding the need to call six.text_type() ourselves.

Replace the remaining use with string concatenation.

Suggested by:	Sean McGinnis in review 188725
Change-Id: Ie53c394d7f31fa1dccfa4ed5c4b514539c77aa05
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-07-13 15:28:34.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/ea20616a88e1a24d880cd5a0b65b7ab4145e157a', 'message': 'StorPool: clean up the last uses of str.format()

directly to LOG.error(), simplifying them in the process by
avoiding the need to call six.text_type() ourselves.

Replace the remaining use with string concatenation.

commit_message:
StorPool: clean up the last uses of str.format()

Replace three logging uses of str.format() with parameters passed
directly to LOG.error(), simplifying them in the process by
avoiding the need to call six.text_type() ourselves.

Replace the remaining use with string concatenation.

Suggested by: Sean McGinnis in review 188725
Change-Id: Ie53c394d7f31fa1dccfa4ed5c4b514539c77aa05

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-10 13:32:48.000000000', 'files': ['meta/io.murano/Classes/Environment.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/murano/commit/35496249d19f4b3f086e14dca964edf43fe9356d', 'message': "Removes early creation of Heat stack

Murano environment deployment started with empty stack
creation so that it can be done prior to keystone token expiration
for Heat to establish trusts based on user's token.
When environment does nothing with the stack (for example
all environment applications are HOT based and deploy into their
own stacks) empty stack remains. Because most applications
start their deployment with instance/other resources deployment
stack will be created early anyway. So this strategy is redundant.

Change-Id: Id8ec1df2c83f540b272ef70bd054f70de9da7715
Closes-Bug: #1473129
(cherry picked from commit fc586b949d489343de9894ec92d21990f65a1e32)

commit_message:
Removes early creation of Heat stack

Murano environment deployment started with empty stack
creation so that it can be done prior to keystone token expiration
for Heat to establish trusts based on user's token.
When environment does nothing with the stack (for example
all environment applications are HOT based and deploy into their
own stacks) empty stack remains. Because most applications
start their deployment with instance/other resources deployment
stack will be created early anyway. So this strategy is redundant.

Change-Id: Id8ec1df2c83f540b272ef70bd054f70de9da7715
Closes-Bug: #1473129
(cherry picked from commit fc586b949d489343de9894ec92d21990f65a1e32)

commit_message:
Sahara Shell Action Form

Sahara is implementing a new Shell Action job type, specified at
add-edp-shell-action. Reviews for this feature are at:

- https://review.openstack.org/156795
- https://review.openstack.org/159920

This task will add options and help text to support this job type
in the job creation form (at
openstack_dashboard/dashboards/project/data_processing/jobs).

Change-Id: Iba70e78d51db943952c53ae44629f02e0903864b
Implements: blueprint sahara-shell-action-form

subject: +Document method to avoid rsync filling root drive
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-07-07 17:52:19.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/ee224a6ecb5773a21c87d251faadbeb83994db69', 'message': 'Document method to avoid rsync filling root drive

When rsync pushes to a remote node with an unmounted drive and if
certain steps are not taken, rsync may attempt to write files to
the local drive at the location where the drive was mounted.

There are two suggested solutions for this issue:
  1) Set the permissions for /srv/../ to root:root 655
  2) Mount the drives elsewhere and symlink the drives to /srv/../

The first method ensures that only root and not the swift user
can create folders in the /srv/../ directories.

The second method will prompt a broken link issue if rsync
attempts to write to an unmounted drive.

commit_message:
+Document method to avoid rsync filling root drive

When rsync pushes to a remote node with an unmounted drive and if
certain steps are not taken, rsync may attempt to write files to
the local drive at the location where the drive was mounted.

There are two suggested solutions for this issue:
  1) Set the permissions for all mount points in /srv/node/
       to root:root 755
  2) Mount the drives elsewhere and symlink the drives to /srv/.../

The first method ensures that only root and not the swift user
can write in the /srv/.../ directories.

The second method will prompt a broken link issue if rsync
attempts to write to an unmounted drive.

Change-Id: I60ce4ed9ef8401768d5f78b6806cbb2e2a65303e
Closes-Bug: #1470576
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/03/199203/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Before unmounting the drive, make sure the directory containing the mount point is owned by root (root:root 655). This ensures that rsync will not try to replicate into the root drive once the failed drive is unmounted.

subject: New interface driver for DHCP for routed networking
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-07-01 13:21:15.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/e5fcc275208226cf8c44aa4ce9fb6b35f4aa4dae', 'message': "DHCP agent: support routed VM interfaces as well as bridged

This patch shows a WIP set of changes to the reference Neutron DHCP
agent, for a network implementation in which data to and from VMs is
routed on the compute host instead of being bridged.  It is a logical
accompaniment to (although not strictly implied by) Carl Baldwin's
work on L3 routed networks at [1].

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/196812/

Network implementation context
==============================

In the network implementation for which these DHCP agent changes are
designed:

- the host end of each TAP interface to/from a VM is left unbridged,
  and without an IPv4 address

- therefore, data _from_ a VM falls into the Linux network stack and
  is either delivered locally (if addressed to a local IP address) or
  routed

- the network implementation also installs local routes, one through
  each TAP interface, which allow data to be routed _to_ the locally
  hosted VMs.

DHCP service
============

The question then arises of how to provide DHCP service to those TAP
interfaces, and that is what is answered by this patch.  Its main
points are as follows.

- The (current) trigger for activating all of the following behaviour
  is setting the DHCP agent's interface_driver setting to
  RoutedInterfaceDriver.

- When RoutedInterfaceDriver is in use:

  - Everything is done in the default namespace.

  - The DHCP agent invokes Dnsmasq with modified options, notably
    '--bridge-interface=ns-XXX,tap* --interface=tap*', that tell
    Dnsmasq to listen on all the TAP interfaces and to treat those
    interfaces as aliases of the ns-XXX interface where the DHCP
    context and IP subnet are defined.

  - The ns-XXX interface (for the DHCP port) is created as a dummy
    interface.

  - The ns-XXX interface is given the subnet's gateway IP address,
    instead of a freshly allocated IP address from the subnet.  Care
    is taken at this point to _avoid_ a corresponding IP prefix route
    for the subnet, via the dummy device; as that would obviously go
    nowhere, and it causes a problem known as 'AS puddling' if that
    route is inadvertently exported via BGP to other compute
    hosts (and if there are IP hops between compute hosts).

Status and remaining work
=========================

My team has been running successfully for several months with versions
of these changes based on Icehouse, Juno and Kilo code.  So in that
sense, we know that the changes work.

However I very much doubt that the modified behaviour is being
correctly triggered.  Instead of being triggered by DHCP agent
_config_ (interface_driver=RoutedInterfaceDriver), my feeling is that
it would be better for the trigger to be some flag or property of the
network object coming from the Neutron server/DB.

In [1], Carl Baldwin has proposed a boolean 'l3_only' flag; and Kevin
Benton has suggested a provider network type instead.  There's also
the possibility of using a network flavor - although I'm not clear if
this would be the kind of use case for which flavors are really
intended.

Note also that the meaning needed for the DHCP agent changes here -
i.e. that the TAP interfaces are unbridged - may not be exactly the
same as the meaning of a network-level L3 flag/value - i.e. that you
can't assume there is L2 broadcast connectivity between all ports on
this network.  Multiple flags/triggers may be needed to describe these
nuances.

So, although I doubt that they are close to final form, I've posted
these changes now for the following reasons.

- To support Carl's work at [1], in the form of a concrete set of
  reference implementation changes that I'd like to make, but which
  depend on the API-level justification and model - for L3-only
  networks - that Carl is describing.

- To solicit input on what the correct trigger for the new behaviour
  should be.

- To show the detailed code changes, in case someone feels like
  commenting on those in detail for any other reason.

Please do let me know what you think!

Change-Id: I4dc5ae75f722d079a529ea1ae5f2011a3edbc84e
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-07-19 09:45:04.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/fcbe25fb8ac1dad846039298b876cec1fbbac56f', 'message': "DHCP agent: support routed VM interfaces as well as bridged

This patch enhances the reference Neutron DHCP agent to handle the
'routed' network implementation [1] in which data to and from VMs is
routed on the compute host instead of being bridged.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/198439/

DHCP service
============

Per [1], the host end of each TAP interface to/from a VM is left
unbridged, and without an IPv4 address.  The question then arises of
how to provide DHCP service to those TAP interfaces, and that is what
is answered by this patch.  Its main points are as follows.

- The trigger for activating all of the following behaviour is setting
  the DHCP agent's interface_driver setting to RoutedInterfaceDriver.

- When RoutedInterfaceDriver is in use:

  - Everything is done in the default namespace.

  - The DHCP agent invokes Dnsmasq with modified options, notably
    '--bridge-interface=ns-XXX,tap* --interface=tap*', that tell
    Dnsmasq to listen on all the TAP interfaces and to treat those
    interfaces as aliases of the ns-XXX interface where the DHCP
    context and IP subnet are defined.

  - The ns-XXX interface (for the DHCP port) is created as a dummy
    interface.

  - The ns-XXX interface is given the subnet's gateway IP address,
    instead of a freshly allocated IP address from the subnet.  Care
    is taken at this point to _avoid_ a corresponding IP prefix route
    for the subnet, via the dummy device; as that would obviously go
    nowhere, and it causes a problem known as 'AS puddling' if that
    route is inadvertently exported via BGP to other compute
    hosts (and if there are IP hops between compute hosts).

Change-Id: I4dc5ae75f722d079a529ea1ae5f2011a3edbc84e

"}, {'number': 9, 'created': '2015-07-27 13:56:18.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/8ce9472f28d00cc7b2e3f34f6b1ec86a2084e1f1', 'message': "RoutedInterfaceDriver: new interface driver for DHCP for routed networking

This change adds an interface driver that combines with the reference
Neutron DHCP agent to provide DHCP service to unbridged TAP interfaces
on the local compute host.  This is what is needed when using a
'routed' network implementation [1] in which data to and from VMs is
routed on the compute host instead of being bridged.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/198439/

Use of this interface driver should be triggered by the following
settings in one of the config files that the DHCP agent reads.

    interface_driver = neutron.agent.linux.interface.RoutedInterfaceDriver
    use_namespaces = False

Key points of its implementation are as follows.

- Everything is done in the default namespace.

- The DHCP agent invokes Dnsmasq with modified options, notably
  '--bridge-interface=ns-XXX,tap* --interface=tap*', that tell Dnsmasq
  to listen on all the TAP interfaces and to treat those interfaces as
  aliases of the ns-XXX interface where the DHCP context and IP subnet
  are defined.

- The ns-XXX interface (for the DHCP port) is created as a dummy
  interface.

- The ns-XXX interface is given the subnet's gateway IP address,
  instead of a freshly allocated IP address from the subnet.  Care is
  taken at this point to _avoid_ a corresponding IP prefix route for
  the subnet, via the dummy device; as that would obviously go
  nowhere, and it causes a problem known as 'AS puddling' if that
  route is inadvertently exported via BGP to other compute hosts (and
  if there are IP hops between compute hosts).

Related-Bug: #1472704
Change-Id: I4dc5ae75f722d079a529ea1ae5f2011a3edbc84e

commit_message:
New interface driver for DHCP for routed networking

This change adds an interface driver that combines with the reference
Neutron DHCP agent to provide DHCP service to unbridged TAP interfaces
on the local compute host.  This is what is needed when using a
'routed' network implementation [1] in which data to and from VMs is
routed on the compute host instead of being bridged.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/198439/

Use of this interface driver should be triggered by the following
settings in one of the config files that the DHCP agent reads.

    interface_driver = neutron.agent.linux.interface.RoutedInterfaceDriver
    use_namespaces = False

Key points of its implementation are as follows.

- Everything is done in the default namespace.

- The DHCP agent invokes Dnsmasq with modified options, notably
  '--bridge-interface=ns-XXX,tap* --interface=tap*', that tell Dnsmasq
  to listen on all the TAP interfaces and to treat those interfaces as
  aliases of the ns-XXX interface where the DHCP context and IP subnet
  are defined.

- The ns-XXX interface (for the DHCP port) is created as a dummy
  interface.

- The ns-XXX interface is given the subnet's gateway IP address,
  instead of a freshly allocated IP address from the subnet.

- The on-link route for the subnet, which Linux creates automatically,
  must be deleted, since other addresses on that subnet are not in
  fact available via the dummy device.

Partial-Bug: #1472704
Change-Id: I4dc5ae75f722d079a529ea1ae5f2011a3edbc84e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/78/197578/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if self.device_manager.bridged(): cmd = [ 'dnsmasq', '--no-hosts', '--no-resolv', '--strict-order', '--bind-interfaces', '--interface=%s' % self.interface_name, '--except-interface=lo', '--pid-file=%s' % pid_file, '--dhcp-hostsfile=%s' % self.get_conf_file_name('host'), '--addn-hosts=%s' % self.get_conf_file_name('addn_hosts'), '--dhcp-optsfile=%s' % self.get_conf_file_name('opts'), '--dhcp-leasefile=%s' % self.get_conf_file_name('leases'), '--dhcp-match=set:ipxe,175', ] else: # When the DHCP port and VM TAP interfaces are not # bridged, we change the dnsmasq invocation as follows. # --interface=tap* # to listen on all TAP interfaces # --bind-dynamic instead of --bind-interfaces, to # "}, {'number': 5, 'created': '2015-08-04 02:50:34.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/4aa9be7aea484f7a7609b2f2e17765f9be84db93', 'message': 'JSCS Cleanup - style guide cleanup for Launch Instance wizard

Following John Papa's style guide
https://github.com/johnpapa/angular-styleguide,
this patch refactors the Angular code for Launch Instance wizard.

Note that the construction of the Launch Instance wizard precludes
applying JP's "controller as" rule to the top level wizard controller
itself; doing so breaks the *many* implicit parent accesses throughout
the wizard sub controllers (implicit parent scope accesses are not
possible using the "controller as" style). Fixing that is potentially
a flow-on tech-debt fix that is outside of the scope of this
patch - it'll be a bunch of work!

I also noticed a trivial bugfix while addressing this. It could be
broken out into a separate patch, but we have enough patches already ;)

Change-Id: Ie6a1fdca1da60259adbb65c36a9829b001ae752b
Partially-Implements: blueprint jscs-cleanup
Closes-Bug: 1481135

commit_message:
JSCS Cleanup - style guide cleanup for Launch Instance wizard

Following John Papa's style guide
https://github.com/johnpapa/angular-styleguide,
this patch refactors the Angular code for Launch Instance wizard.

Note that the construction of the Launch Instance wizard precludes
applying JP's "controller as" rule to the top level wizard controller
itself; doing so breaks the *many* implicit parent accesses throughout
the wizard sub controllers (implicit parent scope accesses are not
possible using the "controller as" style). Fixing that is potentially
a flow-on tech-debt fix that is outside of the scope of this
patch - it'll be a bunch of work!

I also noticed a trivial bugfix while addressing this. It could be
broken out into a separate patch, but we have enough patches already ;)

Change-Id: Ie6a1fdca1da60259adbb65c36a9829b001ae752b
Partially-Implements: blueprint jscs-cleanup
Closes-Bug: 1481135

deleted_lines: function LaunchInstanceModalController($scope, $modal, $window, modalSpec) { $scope.openLaunchInstanceWizard = openLaunchInstanceWizard; function openLaunchInstanceWizard(launchContext) {

subject: Improve List Role Assignments Filters Performance
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-11-25 20:46:34.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/e672e16160ff7380d75eef84bc04a1b54fbe01c7', 'message': 'Improve list role assignments filters performance

When listing role assignments, we have the option
to filter them by actor, target and role. The
current implementation uses the standard
filtering the V3.wrap_collection. Given the large
number of individual assignments, this is pretty
inefficient.

This patch allows the controller to pass the
filters into the driver call, so the driver
filter the results itself and as result, then the
list size is kept a minimum.

Co-Authored-By: Rodrigo Duarte <rodrigods@lsd.ufcg.edu.br>

Change-Id: I20569a201f5cd4467a4891920255993c04dccda2
Closes-Bug: 1359231

'}, {'number': 12, 'created': '2015-01-21 12:08:03.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/af49c4ba534ba944b0ed60cee09c18e0be59a57d', 'message': 'Improve List Role Assignments Filters Performance

When listing role assignments, we have the option
to filter them by actor, target and role. The
current implementation uses the standard
filtering the V3.wrap_collection. Given the large
number of individual assignments, this is pretty
inefficient.

This patch allows the controller to pass the
filters into the driver call, so the driver
filter the results itself and as result, then the
list size is kept a minimum.

Co-Authored-By: Rodrigo Duarte <rodrigods@lsd.ufcg.edu.br>

Closes-Bug: 1359231

Change-Id: I20569a201f5cd4467a4891920255993c04dccda2

'}, {'number': 38, 'created': '2015-08-01 13:09:42.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/0bcd4e40290da9718380482651e79523555df9d1', 'message': 'Improve List Role Assignments Filters Performance

When listing role assignments, we have the option
to filter them by actor, target and role. The
current implementation uses the standard
filtering the V3.wrap_collection. Given the large
number of individual assignments, this is pretty
inefficient.

This patch allows the controller to pass the
filters into the driver call, so the driver
filter the results itself and as result, then the
list size is kept a minimum.

A crucial byproduct of this change is that follow-on
patches can refactor a number of manager methods
related to effective assignments to simple call
this one rather than duplicate the algorithms
around the assignment backend.

Co-Authored-By: Henry Nash <henryn@linux.vnet.ibm.com>
Co-Authored-By: Rodrigo Duarte <rodrigods@lsd.ufcg.edu.br>

Implements: bp list-role-assignments-performance

Change-Id: I20569a201f5cd4467a4891920255993c04dccda2
'}, {'number': 39, 'created': '2015-08-02 08:46:53.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/73d587ca4b7ecc1b73a6163b60d88f68945ee023', 'message': 'Improve List Role Assignments Filters Performance

to filter them by actor, target and role. The

number of individual assignments, this is pretty

This patch allows the controller to pass the
filters into the driver call, so the driver
filter the results itself and as result, then the
list size is kept a minimum.

A crucial byproduct of this change is that follow-on
patches can refactor a number of manager methods
related to effective assignments to simple call
this one rather than duplicate the algorithms
around the assignment backend.

Co-Authored-By: Henry Nash <henryn@linux.vnet.ibm.com>

Implements: bp list-role-assignments-performance

commit_message:
Improve List Role Assignments Filters Performance

When listing role assignments, we have the option
to filter them by actor, target and role. The
current implementation uses the standard
filtering the V3.wrap_collection. Given the large
number of individual assignments, this is pretty
inefficient.

This patch allows the controller to pass the
filters into the driver call, so the driver
filter the results itself and as result, then the
list size is kept a minimum.

The restful testing that is already in place for
listing assignments will still act as an effective
test, since there is no change to external functionality
with this patch. However, a crucial byproduct of this
change is that follow-on patches can refactor a number
of manager methods related to effective assignments to
simply call this one rather than duplicate the algorithms
around the assignment backend. In order to ensure those
different usage patterns are tested, a separate series
of patches follow this to add manager-level testing of
this new assignment listing capability.

Co-Authored-By: Henry Nash <henryn@linux.vnet.ibm.com>
Co-Authored-By: Rodrigo Duarte <rodrigods@lsd.ufcg.edu.br>

Implements: bp list-role-assignments-performance

Change-Id: I20569a201f5cd4467a4891920255993c04dccda2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/02/137202/32 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def list_role_assignments(self, role_id=None, user_id=None, group_ids=None, project_id=None, domain_id=None, inherited_to_projects=None): if role_id and assignment['role_id'] != role_id: continue if user_id and assignment.get('user_id') != user_id: continue if group_ids and assignment.get('group_id') not in group_ids: continue if project_id and assignment['project_id'] != project_id: continue

commit_message:
JSCS Cleanup-style guide cleanup for Magic Search

This fixes eslint rule violations. Also groups tests related to
initializing and removing facets.

Change-Id: I2b8a9988d1f389939931fad75b25c6cedd4fa4f8
Partially-Implements: blueprint jscs-cleanup
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/27/199327/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if (angular.isUndefined(value.options)) { if (angular.isDefined($scope.textSearch)) { if (angular.isUndefined($scope.facetSelected)) {
deleted_lines: if (value.options === undefined) { if ($scope.textSearch !== undefined) { if ($scope.facetSelected === undefined) {

subject: libvirt: set caps on maximum live migration time
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-06 17:52:36.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/83e96e378f55c0f53b26efb58276df4d6e4ae86a', 'message': "libvirt: set caps on maximum live migration time

Currently Nova launches live migration and then just leaves it
to run, assuming it'll eventually finish. If the guest is
dirtying memory quicker than the network can transfer it, it
is entirely possible that a migration will never complete. In
such a case it is highly undesirable to leave it running
forever since it wastes valuable CPU and network resources
Rather than trying to come up with a new policy for aborting
migration, this copies the logic already successfully in use
by the oVirt project in VDSM.

This introduces two new host level configuration parameters
that cloud administrators can use to ensure migrations which
don't appear likely to complete will be aborted. First is
an overall cap on the total running time of migration. The
configured value is scaled by the number of GB of guest RAM,
since larger guests will obviously take proportionally longer
to migrate. The second is a timeout that is applied when Nova
detects that memory is being dirtied faster than it can be
transferred. It tracks a low watermark of data remaining and
if that low watermark doesn't decreased in the given time,
it assumes the VM is stuck and aborts migration

Closes-bug: #1429220
Change-Id: I461affe6c85aaf2a6bf6e8749586bfbfe0ebc146

"}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2015-05-20 10:44:17.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/52422fefb23352e5562ec441c6df871c8ad57aca', 'message': "libvirt: set caps on maximum live migration time

Currently Nova launches live migration and then just leaves it
to run, assuming it'll eventually finish. If the guest is
dirtying memory quicker than the network can transfer it, it
is entirely possible that a migration will never complete. In
such a case it is highly undesirable to leave it running
forever since it wastes valuable CPU and network resources
Rather than trying to come up with a new policy for aborting
migration in OpenStack, copy the existing logic that is
successfully battle tested by the oVirt project in VDSM.

This introduces two new host level configuration parameters
that cloud administrators can use to ensure migrations which
don't appear likely to complete will be aborted. First is
an overall cap on the total running time of migration. The
configured value is scaled by the number of GB of guest RAM,
since larger guests will obviously take proportionally longer
to migrate. The second is a timeout that is applied when Nova
detects that memory is being dirtied faster than it can be
transferred. It tracks a low watermark of data remaining and
if that low watermark doesn't decrease in the given time,
it assumes the VM is stuck and aborts migration

NB with the default values for the config parameters, the code
for detecting stuck migrations is only going to kick in for
guests which have more than 2 GB of RAM allocated, as for
smaller guests the overall time limit will abort migration
before this happens. This is reasonable as small guests are
less likely to get stuck during migration, as the network
will generally be able to keep up with dirtying data well
enough to get to a point where the final switchover can be
performed.

Closes-bug: #1429220
DocImpact: two new libvirt configuration parameters in
           nova.conf allow the administrator to control
           length of migration before aborting it
Change-Id: I461affe6c85aaf2a6bf6e8749586bfbfe0ebc146

that cloud administrators can use to ensure migrations which
don't appear likely to complete will be aborted. First is
an overall cap on the total running time of migration. The
configured value is scaled by the number of GB of guest RAM,
since larger guests will obviously take proportionally longer
to migrate. The second is a timeout that is applied when Nova
detects that memory is being dirtied faster than it can be
transferred. It tracks a low watermark of data remaining and
if that low watermark doesn't decrease in the given time,
it assumes the VM is stuck and aborts migration

NB with the default values for the config parameters, the code
for detecting stuck migrations is only going to kick in for
guests which have more than 2 GB of RAM allocated, as for
smaller guests the overall time limit will abort migration
before this happens. This is reasonable as small guests are
less likely to get stuck during migration, as the network
will generally be able to keep up with dirtying data well
enough to get to a point where the final switchover can be
performed.

Related-bug: #1429220
DocImpact: two new libvirt configuration parameters in
           nova.conf allow the administrator to control
           length of migration before aborting it
Change-Id: I461affe6c85aaf2a6bf6e8749586bfbfe0ebc146

commit_message:
libvirt: set caps on maximum live migration time

Currently Nova launches live migration and then just leaves it
to run, assuming it'll eventually finish. If the guest is
dirtying memory quicker than the network can transfer it, it
is entirely possible that a migration will never complete. In
such a case it is highly undesirable to leave it running
forever since it wastes valuable CPU and network resources
Rather than trying to come up with a new policy for aborting
migration in OpenStack, copy the existing logic that is
successfully battle tested by the oVirt project in VDSM.

This introduces two new host level configuration parameters
that cloud administrators can use to ensure migrations which
don't appear likely to complete will be aborted. First is
an overall cap on the total running time of migration. The
configured value is scaled by the number of GB of guest RAM,
since larger guests will obviously take proportionally longer
to migrate. The second is a timeout that is applied when Nova
detects that memory is being dirtied faster than it can be
transferred. It tracks a low watermark of data remaining and
if that low watermark doesn't decrease in the given time,
it assumes the VM is stuck and aborts migration

NB with the default values for the config parameters, the code
for detecting stuck migrations is only going to kick in for
guests which have more than 2 GB of RAM allocated, as for
smaller guests the overall time limit will abort migration
before this happens. This is reasonable as small guests are
less likely to get stuck during migration, as the network
will generally be able to keep up with dirtying data well
enough to get to a point where the final switchover can be
performed.

Related-bug: #1429220
DocImpact: two new libvirt configuration parameters in
           nova.conf allow the administrator to control
           length of migration before aborting it
Change-Id: I461affe6c85aaf2a6bf6e8749586bfbfe0ebc146
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/54/162254/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: completion_timeout = int( CONF.libvirt.live_migration_completion_timeout * ram_gb) progress_timeout = CONF.libvirt.live_migration_progress_timeout progress_time = start progress_watermark = None abort = False if ((progress_watermark is None) or (progress_watermark > info.data_remaining)): progress_watermark = info.data_remaining progress_time = now if (now - progress_time) > progress_timeout: LOG.warn(_LW("Live migration stuck for %d sec, aborting"), progress_timeout, instance=instance) abort = True if elapsed > completion_timeout: LOG.warn(_LW("Live migration not completed after %d sec"), completion_timeout, instance=instance) abort = True if abort: try: dom.abortJob() except libvirt.libvirtError as e: LOG.warn(_LW("Failed to abort migration %s"), e, instance=instance) raise if info.data_remaining > progress_watermark: lg(_LI("Data remaining %(remaining)d bytes, " "low watermark %(watermark)d bytes " "%(last)d seconds ago"), {"remaining": info.data_remaining, "watermark": progress_watermark, "last": (now - progress_time)}, instance=instance)

'}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2015-05-20 10:44:17.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/3fbe831915ada9a8932660eb8a424336f58a1bda', 'message': 'libvirt: support management of downtime during migration

Currently live migration runs with the default maximum downtime

migration of large VMs to ever complete. Rather than trying to

Note that setting the downtime step delay based on guest RAM size
is an inexact science, as RAM size is only one factor influencing
success of migration. Just as important is the rate of dirtying
data in the guest, but this is based on guest workload which is
not something Nova has visibility into. The bottleneck is the
network which needs to be able to keep up with the dirtying of
data in the guest. The greater the overall RAM size, the more
time is required to transfer the total guest memory. So for
larger guest sizes, we need to allow greater time for the guest
to attempt to successfully migrate before increasing the max
downtime. Scaling downtime step delay according to the overall
guest RAM size is a reasonable, albeit not foolproof, way to
tune migration to increase chances of success.

This adds three host level config parameters which admins can
use to control the base downtime value and the rate at which
downtime is allowed to be increased during migration.

commit_message:
libvirt: support management of downtime during migration

Currently live migration runs with the default maximum downtime
setting defined by QEMU. This is often inadequate to allow
migration of large VMs to ever complete. Rather than trying to
invent a new policy for changing downtime in OpenStack, copy
the existing logic that is successfully battle tested by the
oVirt project in VDSM.

Note that setting the downtime step delay based on guest RAM size
is an inexact science, as RAM size is only one factor influencing
success of migration. Just as important is the rate of dirtying
data in the guest, but this is based on guest workload which is
not something Nova has visibility into. The bottleneck is the
network which needs to be able to keep up with the dirtying of
data in the guest. The greater the overall RAM size, the more
time is required to transfer the total guest memory. So for
larger guest sizes, we need to allow greater time for the guest
to attempt to successfully migrate before increasing the max
downtime. Scaling downtime step delay according to the overall
guest RAM size is a reasonable, albeit not foolproof, way to
tune migration to increase chances of success.

This adds three host level config parameters which admins can
use to control the base downtime value and the rate at which
downtime is allowed to be increased during migration.

Related-bug: #1429220
DocImpact: three new libvirt configuration parameters in
           nova.conf allow the administrator to control
           the maximum permitted downtime for migration
           making migration more likely to complete for
           large VMs.
Change-Id: I1992ffe9d3b2ff8d436cf1c419af9a238a8fecd8

added_lines: def test_live_migration_downtime_steps(self): self.flags(live_migration_downtime=400, group='libvirt') self.flags(live_migration_downtime_steps=10, group='libvirt') self.flags(live_migration_downtime_delay=30, group='libvirt') drvr = libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver(fake.FakeVirtAPI(), False) steps = drvr._migration_downtime_steps(3.0) self.assertEqual([ (90, 41), (180, 41), (270, 43), (360, 47), (450, 53), (540, 66), (630, 90), (720, 137), (810, 227), (900, 400), ], list(steps))

commit_message:
Add RDO testing repo for CentOS

To be consistent with the yum repos provided by the rdo-release RPM

Change-Id: Ie2c6fef1d0566173c31c1e70d94c69e63733a6ce
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cookbook-openstack-common refs/changes/86/207286/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: yum_repository "RDO-#{node['openstack']['release']}-testing" do description "OpenStack RDO testing repo for #{node['openstack']['release']}" baseurl node['openstack']['yum']['testing-uri'] gpgcheck false enabled true action repo_action end

subject: Remove quotes from subshell call in tools/split.sh
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-07 13:20:15.000000000', 'files': ['tools/split.sh'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/ed9703e3edc1290b57132e408e2d1c1d021d9477', 'message': 'Remove quotes from subshell call in tools/split.sh

Always no quotes for $() statement.

We don't need quotes to hold blanks in result:
 # i=$(echo 1 2 3)
 # echo $i
 1 2 3
 #

These quotes can make something wrong in some case:
 # i=$(echo '!')
 #
 # i="$(echo '!')"
 -bash: !: event not found
 #

No real problem for current code in split.sh, only to use a
better code style.

Change-Id: Ib86d59e10be0aca4774ad2fc656915a96b1b6c74
Signed-off-by: Zhao Lei <zhaolei@cn.fujitsu.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Remove quotes from subshell call in tools/split.sh

Always no quotes for $() statement.

We don't need quotes to hold blanks in result:
 # i=$(echo 1 2 3)
 # echo $i
 1 2 3
 #

These quotes can make something wrong in some case:
 # i=$(echo '!')
 #
 # i="$(echo '!')"
 -bash: !: event not found
 #

No real problem for current code in split.sh, only to use a
better code style.

Change-Id: Ib86d59e10be0aca4774ad2fc656915a96b1b6c74
Signed-off-by: Zhao Lei <zhaolei@cn.fujitsu.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/08/210408/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: file_root=$(git rev-list --reverse HEAD -- $file | head -n1)

commit_message:
Remove 'rabbitmq-plugins' package in ha-guide

The package 'rabbitmq-plugins' is not a package on Ubuntu/Debian,
the rabbitmq-plugins script is available when the 'rabbitmq-server'
package is installed, so remove 'rabbitmq-plugins' package for the
On Ubuntu and Debian part in OpenStack High Availability Guide.

Closes-Bug: #1382092

Change-Id: Id58c5eb105394ab849d2b2bdec7ff2ec9f78fc63

subject: Make '_create_router' function handle Boolean kwargs correctly
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-06 07:57:33.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/02e958c2c8a5074ffae8c0d917bcf7d04574c015', 'message': "Make '_create_router' function handle Boolean kwargs correctly

The function allows arbitrary kw arguments to be specificed,
which are then passed in the create router REST API call.
The code contains a sanity check, an 'if' clause, to ensure that
the value of the kw argument is not empty. However, as it reads
that check does not work with Boolean kw arguments.

This patch fixes the faulty 'if' clause so that it checks that
the kw argument is not None. This makes it support also Boolean
kw arguments.

Closes-Bug: #1482108
Change-Id: I5618dc4d5c803c7614dd1f579db3c79928007fb6
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-08-07 10:36:00.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/tests/unit/extensions/test_l3.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/e28aa9761751d7fa12dba1c35076c3c975b7cd3f', 'message': "Make '_create_router' function handle Boolean kwargs correctly

The function allows arbitrary kw arguments to be specificed.
Those kw arguments whose key is specified in the function
parameter 'arg_list' are then passed in the create router REST
API call.

The code line that checks if a kw argument key is included in
'arg_list' does not work with Boolean kw arguments. Nor does it
work with None kw argument values. This is a limitation as
tests in inheriting classes may need such kw arguments.

This patch fixes the faulty 'if' clause so that it simply
checks that the kw argument key is in 'arg_list'. This makes it
support Boolean kw arguments and kw arguments with value None.

Closes-Bug: #1482108
Change-Id: I5618dc4d5c803c7614dd1f579db3c79928007fb6
"}]
commit_message:
Make '_create_router' function handle Boolean kwargs correctly

The function allows arbitrary kw arguments to be specificed.
Those kw arguments whose key is specified in the function
parameter 'arg_list' are then passed in the create router REST
API call.

The code line that checks if a kw argument key is included in
'arg_list' does not work with Boolean kw arguments. Nor does it
work with None kw argument values. This is a limitation as
tests in inheriting classes may need such kw arguments.

This patch fixes the faulty 'if' clause so that it simply
checks that the kw argument key is in 'arg_list'. This makes it
support Boolean kw arguments and kw arguments with value None.

Closes-Bug: #1482108
Change-Id: I5618dc4d5c803c7614dd1f579db3c79928007fb6

commit_message:
Correctly intialized olso config fixture for TestClientHTTPBasicAuth

Otherwise it can fail intermittently when run with other tests or
consistently when run in isolation.

Change-Id: Ib0674c93c8e41ab610fb799470a99fa427dfd14f
Closes-Bug: #1482740

commit_message:
Fixed experimental job for Nova API services under Apache2

If variable API_WORKERS equals 0 Apache will fail because count
of processes can not be equal 0.

Change-Id: I2dabbdd77025c87c4411a4774e7069e90cdb95de

commit_message:
remove branch limiting for ec2api functional jobs.

since ec2api has stable/kilo branch it needs functional tests
for new patchsets to stable/kilo.
So branch limitier has removed from zuul layout.conf in this patchset.

Change-Id: Ib8fba69a640b9d824b1c1165ff4376bbd8910949
